ssf.name: HydroFLOW Water Conditioners
ssf.one_sentence_description: A Electronic Water Conditioner that reduces limescale, prevents bio-fouling & offers chemical-free solutions globally
ssf.public_short_description:
Industry relies on water for many different purposes. Its unique properties mean that it is particularly efficient at transferring heat, so water is vital to both cooling and heating applications. 

When the state of water is changed, for instance if the water is heated it is less able to hold on to the minerals dissolved in it; they precipitate out to form a hard mass on the surfaces of pipes and equipment, known as calcium carbonate or "limescale," but also phosphate or sulphate scales.  

The layer of scale also forms a thermal barrier, meaning that heat transfer is greatly reduced and leading to major inefficiencies - just 2mm of scale can lead to an efficiency loss of 20%. 

HydroFLOW units induce an electric field into the water and the pipe network to prevent the build-up of hard mineral scale without adding chemicals to the water, keeping equipment running at maximum efficiency and for longer.
ssf.environmental_benefit:
The environmental benefits of the solution vary by application and the alternative treatments it replaces. 

In the cooling tower case study, the following improvements were recorded: 75% reduction in antiscalant and biocide use, 85% reduction in water consumption, 50% reduction in maintenance frequency, and 10% reduction in electricity use. 

By preventing scale and removing biofilm, antiscalant chemicals were eliminated entirely, and biocide use was reduced to just 25% of previous levels. Scale prevention enabled the system to operate with harder water, reducing the need for water replacement and saving significant volumes. With heat exchange surfaces kept clean, energy efficiency was preserved, leading to lower electricity usage. 

These outcomes demonstrate substantial environmental gains through reduced chemical use, water savings, and lower energy consumption—key indicators of sustainable impact.
ssf.economical_benefit:
Economic benefits vary by application but generally include savings on water, energy, chemicals, and maintenance. 

In case studies, customers have reported: $19,600/year in water savings, $20,000/year in sewage charges, $13,000/year from reduced antiscalant and biocide use, and $34,500/year in energy savings. 

Additional benefits include $5,000/year in reduced labour and cleaning, $1,000/year from eliminating salt in softeners, and reduced downtime. Units have no consumables, require minimal maintenance, and use less than 65W of power. 

In systems already operating at peak efficiency, the main benefit is chemical savings. Where untreated scale is present, the primary gain is energy efficiency. In many cases, both apply—making HydroFLOW a highly cost-effective solution across diverse sectors.
ssf.ss_title: Maximising Cooling System Efficiency at a Fortune 100 Company with HydroFLOW
ssf.ss_description: A Fortune 100 company installed a HydroFLOW unit at its 595,600 sq ft corporate HQ to boost sustainability beyond its existing LEED Gold certification. The unit was placed on the open loop condenser of two 1000-ton cooling towers. Goals included reducing water and sewage usage, chemical consumption, energy and maintenance needs, and extending equipment life. A third-party audit compared two years of historical data to one year of HydroFLOW operation to assess performance improvements.
ssf.ss_case_study_impact: The HydroFLOW unit prevented limescale and biofouling in chillers and cooling towers, boosting efficiency and enabling higher water reuse. Environmental benefits included 85% less discharge water, 75% fewer chemicals, and 50% less maintenance. Energy use dropped 10%. Economically, the system saved $73,400 annually in water and energy, with a positive Net Present Value of $4.76M over the building’s 50-year lifespan, highlighting strong environmental and financial returns.
ssf.technical_aspects:
The Product consists of a transducer unit that is secured to a water pipe (ref [11]). A ring comprising sections of ferrite material is assembled which passes through the body of the unit and around the pipe. The transducer induces an electromagnetic field into the ring, which in turn induces an electric field into the pipe and the fluid contained therein. The electric field travels both upstream and downstream, throughout the pipe network. The electric field causes ions in the water to form as "clusters". When the water is heated (or the water becomes otherwise "supersaturated" i.e. unable to hold on to the ions in solution) the ions form crystals. Crystal formation requires a starting point, or "nucleation site." without HydroFLOW, the nucleation site is the equipment surface and the crystals form a hard mass bonded to the surface - this is scale. With HydroFLOW, the clusters formed act as preferred nucleation sites, so the minerals form fine powder-like crystals in suspension in the water. These are carried out by the water flow rather than adhering to the heat exchange surface. This allows systems to run on water with a high concentration of minerals, i.e. "hard water" while not experiencing the problems of hard scale (Ref. [11]). As well as saving money on ongoing salt or chemical replenishment and preventing their discharge into the sewage system, the treatment can reduce amount of water that needs to be discarded in order to maintain systems such as cooling towers operating effectively, and can also maintain maximum efficiency by keeping heat exchange surfaces clean.

Since being initially awarded the Solar Impulse label, Hydroflow products are being increasingly used in larger scale piping systems above 500mm diameter, typically in larger industrial systems or power stations. This has required the use of new products able to cope with the increased scale. In order to ensure the signal is fully applied around the circumference of the pipe, the signal is applied at multiple points and synchronised to ensure it remains fully effective. This approach is been covered by a patent ( https://patents.google.com/patent/GB2484968B/en ). 

Another aspect that is becoming more prevalent since the awarding of the Solar Impulse label is the importance of biofouling reduction in marketplace, particularly in larger systems. Many of the cooling systems of larger facilities (particularly power stations) do not rely on municipal (treated) water and instead use sea water or water from lakes or rivers.  This is naturally more prone to biofouling problems, both biofilm and larger "macrofoulers" such as mussels. Treating this with chemical methods is not only difficult and expensive due to the large volumes of water involved, but releases harmful substances into the environment. 

The specification of the units is based on pipe O/D diameter, rather than flow rate or water quality. Units cover the full range of pipes sizes in industry, typically from 60mm diameter to around 300mm. Larger units are available, and although their use is rare it is becoming less so. The products consist of a transducer, approx 300 x 200 x 100 mm, and a ferrite ring which is assembled around the pipe. The ferrite ring is assembled from individual ferrite bars of approximately 125 x 20 x 30mm. The transducer body is made of an aluminium and polycarbonate casing. There are no moving parts or consumables so the lifetime of the units is typically 10 years (guaranteed for 3 years). The units require  a single-phase electrical supply (either 240 of 110V) but use a maximum power level of 65W (typically only 20W). They have the facility to be wired to a BMS system to monitor operation as standard. For very large units, multiple transducer units are connected to the same ferrite ring, depending o the size of the pipe. This does not increase the amount of space required significantly as the transducers are attached circumferentially around the pipe.
ssf.human_assets:
Hydropath Technology began in 1992, founded by Dr Danny Stefanini with a vision to create a cleaner, smarter way to treat water. What started as a family-run business quickly gained recognition when early HydroFLOW prototypes—tested by British Gas—showed clear savings in maintenance and energy. That success helped turn a bold idea into a growing company, now based in Nottingham and supported by a close team in the UK and a global network of distributors.

The credibility of our solution comes from decades of experience in the field. HydroFLOW wasn’t created in isolation—it was shaped by engineers, scientists, and partners working directly with real systems, under real conditions. We’ve seen our technology deliver results in everything from commercial buildings and factories to power stations and farms. Every project has helped us evolve and refine what we do.

We’re a small team—around 14 of us in the UK—but we work closely together, drawing on each other’s knowledge and ideas. Our flat, collaborative culture means everyone contributes, whether it’s in product development, technical support, or customer care. We believe the best ideas come when people feel supported and heard.

Sustainability is at the heart of our business. Our bike-to-work scheme is just one example of how we encourage lower-impact choices in daily life. We also look for ways to reduce energy use and waste in our operations. These values carry through into our technology, which helps clients cut chemical use, save energy, and extend equipment life—all while reducing their environmental footprint.

HydroFLOW is more than a product—it’s a result of years of learning, supported by a strong community of people who care about doing things the right way. When clients choose Hydropath, they’re choosing proven expertise, real partnership, and a shared commitment to a better future.
ssf.external_threats:
Total Addressable Market (TAM)
Hydropath's TAM encompasses the global water treatment market, which includes various segments such as water purification, wastewater treatment, and water conditioning. While specific figures for the entire water treatment market vary, it's a substantial and growing industry driven by increasing water scarcity, industrialization, and environmental concerns.

Serviceable Addressable Market (SAM)
Hydropath's SAM focuses on specific sectors where HydroFLOW® technology is most applicable:

* Residential Water Treatment: Addressing limescale and water quality issues in homes.
* Commercial and Industrial Water Systems: Including applications in cooling towers, boilers, and manufacturing processes where water conditioning is critical.
* Agricultural and Irrigation Systems: Enhancing water efficiency and reducing biofouling in irrigation equipment.

These segments represent a significant portion of the overall water treatment market, aligning with Hydropath's product offerings.

Share of Market (SOM)
Hydropath's SOM is modest compared to major players in the water treatment industry. However, our presence in over 70 countries through a network of distributors indicates a niche but global footprint. 

Without specific market share data, it's challenging to quantify our exact SOM. Nonetheless, our specialized technology and international reach suggest a focused market presence within our targeted segments.
ssf.mainstream_alternative: The most common mainstream alternative, particularly in cooling towers, is chemical treatment (anti-scalant and biocide) plus continued blowdown (discarding water). This is the alternative used in the case studies presented. Antiscalants are composed of anionic polymers. These are designed to keep the ions which cause scale in solution, preventing them from forming a scale deposit on the heat exchange surfaces. Chemical biocide is used to kill the bacteria living in the cooling tower water.
ssf.business_opportunity:
The most common alternative to HydroFLOW in the market is chemical treatment, which includes the use of antiscalants, corrosion inhibitors, and water softening systems. While these methods are widely used and understood, they bring ongoing costs, supply chain dependencies, and safety risks. Handling, storing, and dosing chemicals requires strict procedures, regular maintenance, and trained personnel. Increasingly, organisations are under pressure to reduce chemical use for health, environmental, and regulatory reasons.

Our technology treats issues like limescale, biofouling, and corrosion without the need for chemicals. It provides a consistent and reliable solution across a wide range of applications, from residential systems to industries. Because our system does not introduce anything into the water, there are no chemicals to manage, no waste to dispose of, and no safety risks for onsite teams. It is a cleaner, safer, and more sustainable way to maintain water systems.

Other non-chemical technologies do exist, such as magnetic, electromagnetic, and catalytic devices. However, these systems are often limited in scope. Many cannot support large pipe sizes, high-flow systems or require an ongoing flow in order to be able to treat. Some lack third-party validation or show inconsistent results in demanding industrial environments. Our patented signal technology is effective on both small and very large pipework, and is proven in real-world applications across multiple industries.

Backed by a team of experts and a global distributor network, we provide tailored solutions with local support, wherever our systems are installed.

In short, HydroFLOW performs on par with chemical treatment in terms of results, but with none of the associated environmental risks or maintenance. It also outperforms other physical devices in range, scale, cost and proven effectiveness. This makes it a future-focused alternative that meets both operational and sustainability goals.
ssf.status:
Product Innovation and Customization
The company is committed to continuous innovation, exemplified by the development of custom HydroFLOW® units designed for large-scale applications such as cooling towers and power stations. These tailored solutions enable Hydropath to address specific industry needs, thereby expanding its market reach.

OEM Partnerships and Integration
Hydropath collaborates with original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) to integrate HydroFLOW® technology directly into new equipment. This strategy facilitates seamless adoption of their solutions across various applications, from small-scale devices like espresso machines to large industrial systems.

Diversification into Emerging Markets
The company is exploring new applications for its technology, such as wastewater treatment and desalination processes. For instance, studies have demonstrated HydroFLOW®'s effectiveness in reducing membrane scaling in reverse osmosis systems, indicating potential for growth in the water reuse and desalination sectors.

Through these strategic initiatives, Hydropath Technology Ltd is positioning itself for sustainable growth and increased global market penetration in the water treatment industry.
ssf.summary_market_of_application: Suitable for pipe sizes from 15mm up to  660mm as standard, with larger units available on request
ssf.sei_case_study_description: The Client is a Fortune 100 company in the USA (Sysco - please do not publicise this name).The unit was installed in their 595,600 square-foot Corporate Office Headquarters in Huston, Texas. The building already had LEED Gold green building certification of and desired to further improve the environmental performance. A 3rd party report was prepared by McMac Cx, who provide independent auditing of performance. The aim of the project was to reduce water and sewage use, to reduce chemical use, to cut down on maintenance and energy, and to extend equipment life. The unit was installed on the open loop condenser of two 1000 ton cooling towers. The audit compared the historical data from the previous two years to asses a year's operation with HydroFLOW. Data regarding the electricity, water and chemical consumption and sewage use was compiled and analysed using various different approaches, including a Simple Payback calculation to highlight the immediate financial benefits and a Triple Bottom Line Cost-Benefit Analysis (TBA-CBA) to account for the full Environmental, Social and Financial Benefits. The HydroFLOW unit acted to prevent limescale and biofouling in the chillers and cooling towers. As well as reductions in the anti-scalant and biocide chemicals used, ensuring the heat exchange surfaces are free from deposits improved efficiency, and allows the tower to run with higher cycles of concentration (simply put, the water is re-used more before being discharged) which reduces water and sewage use. The results of the trial included: - 85% blow down(discharge) water reduction, which greatly exceeded the 50% goal. - 75% chemical reduction. - 50% reduction in maintenance frequency. - 10% reduction in energy consumption by the cooling towers and chillers. Annual savings on water and energy use were $73,400 using a simple payback analysis, with a positive Net Present Value of$4,760,200 over the building's 50 year useful life. The attached files [5,6,7] show more detail.
ssf.sei_production_phase:
To Produce one unit, the major components comprise of following materials (approx.):
Circuit board 290g
Potting (Epoxy resin) 1500g
Aluminium Extrusion 524g
Ferrite 7200g (varies depending on model. Value is for unit used in example)
Polycarbonate ends 176g
Carboard packaging 1200g

(Data from product specification)

A single unit was used to achieve the results in the submitted case study.

Note that the production is a single-one off process for the solution, whereas the mainstream alternative is a consumable and so has ongoing production throughout its use, in this case $13,000 worth of annually (ref [7], pg.9, section 8a) . We do not have the individual volume/ mass of the chemical used as an alternative (only its financial value) but using a typical figure of $200 for a 25kg barrel, gives $13 000/$200 x 25kg = 1625kg annually of scale inhibitor and biocide. This is an ongoing requirement so the total over the 20 year analysis period is 1625kg/yr x 20yrs = 32 500 kg.
ssf.sei_transport:
A limited number of bespoke components are sourced, worldwide and brought to our UK warehouse.
Aluminium Extrusions 400 km Road
Potting (Epoxy resin) 130 km Road
Ferrite 1200 km (Germany) Road/ Rail
Polycarbonate ends 8000km (China) Sea
Packaging 1km (UK) Road

(Data from product specification and manufacturing information)

These components are sent to our UK manufacturer (5 km) for assembly with the circuit board and the unit returned to our warehouse.
Completed units are despatched to required locations around the world, in this instance Houston Texas (8000km), air.
Again this is a one-off process, unlike continual transport of chemicals used in the mainstream alternative. The alternative requires 32 500 kg of chemicals over a 20 year period. We may estimate typical shipping distance from the factory to the customer as 500km (by road).

UPDATE:

Since initial submission we have gone through a significant program on on-shoring and this data has changes since 2021. Packaging would previously have been purchased in China (4000km) and shipped by sea. UK Manufacturing has been moved closer to our warehouse/ office, reducing road transport to 5km from approx 320 km. 

This process continues and we are onshoring plastics production to the UK as well. Plastics for our smaller domestic units have already been shifted to UK production, with the process underway (moulds shipped, samples produced) for our larger commercial units.
ssf.sei_use_phase:
Environmental benefits vary depending on the application and the alternative treatment used, eg as reduction in of salt discharge into the sewage or reduction of energy use – see other case studies attached.

In the particular study analysed [5,6,7], the unit prevented scale and removed biofilm. This gave savings of $13 000 dollars on antiscalant and biocide (see sections on production, distribution and disposal.)

Limescale was prevented from forming on heat exchange surfaces, and instead caused to form in suspension in the water. This meant the tower could operate with higher hardness water, without concern about scaling on the heat exchanger surfaces. This in turn meant the tower water did not need to be discarded+replaced so often, saving a large volume of water.

Electricity use was also down because prevention of scale and biofilm on heat exchange surfaces meant the maximal heat exchange efficiency was maintained. The benefits of course vary with application, but those listed above are taken from this specific case study.

The savings on electricity and water represent the most significant savings:

Reduction in municipal (drinking) water use of 4,341,024 gallons/yr = 16 432 563 kg per year (Ref 7 pg 8, section 9) plus similar (3,069,224 gallons/ yr) on sewage. This would give 16 432 563 x 20 = 328 651 260 kg total reduction in drinking water use.

This is an 85% reduction compared to the alternative.

Reduction in electricity use (initially 7 322 350 kWh - Ref [7] pg. 13, table line “Annual central plant electricity use”) of 10% (ref [7], pg 8 section 6). This gave a saving of 732 235 kWh = 2 636 046 MJ per year, or 2 636 046 x 20 = 52 720 920 MJ total.

A 50% reduction in maintenance frequency was also achieved (ref [5] slide 4).

Summaries provided in “[5] HQ of Fortune 100 Company – Cooling Towers and Chillers 04-15-2019”and “[6] Summarized Hydroflow TWM 3rd Party Study - April 2019"
Full details are provided in “[7] MCMAC CX – Hydroflow Sysco Report”
ssf.sei_disposal_phase:
A number of the components are directly recyclable, such as the steel banding and brackets, the steel banding, the cables and the aluminium casing. The PCB is disposed of via the UK’s WEEE scheme for electronic waste.

This is contrasted with the mainstream alternative, in which case 32,500 kg of chemicals was discharged to the public sewage system.
ssf.ei_energy_consumption_1: Reduction of energy  consumption (heating fuel and electricity) due to improved efficiency of exchangers of 10% [example, ref 7]
ssf.ei_water_savings_1: Saving on freshwater of 85% [example, ref 7] compared to mainstream alternative
ssf.ei_reduces_waste_1: Saving on water discharged to sewage systems of 85% [example, ref 7]
ssf.ei_reduces_waste_2: Reduction of chemical antiscalant and biocide of 75% [example, ref 7]
ssf.economic:
Economic benefits come from a range of aspects, depending on the application . 

Examples in the case studies presented include: -Metered water savings $19,600/ yr (1), (3) -Savings on sewage charges $20,000/ yr (1) -Savings due to reduction of chemical antiscalant and biocide $13,000/ yr (1) -Savings due to elimination of salt in water softeners $1000 (3) -Reduction of energy consumption due to improved efficiency of exchangers $34,500.00/ yr(1) -Reduced labour/ cleaning costs $5000/ yr (1), (2) -Reduced downtime (1), (2) 

Some or all of these can apply in different installations, even for the same application. E.g., a cooling tower might previously use excessive chemicals to prevent scale and thus run at maximum efficiency. Here the benefit of HydroFLOW is the reduction of chemicals, but no increase inefficiency would be seen (because the exchanger was already clean). In another case, a tower might use no chemicals, thereby leading to a loss of efficiency due to scale. In this situation, the benefit of HydroFLOW would be an increase in efficiency, but no reduction of chemicals would be seen (because none were used previously). Price starts from around £1767. No consumables, minimal energy costs (less than 65W). Payback time typically 1-2yrs. Benefits further detailed in the attached case studies. (1) Case study on cooling towers shows a range of benefits. The most significant financial benefits were due to reduced water and energy use. (2) The case study on "White Liquor" describes an installation where the main financial benefit was a reduction in factory down-time, along with an (unquantified) reduction in labour costs and chemical use for the cleaning process. (3) The case study on "Residential Heat Exchange" is a translation of a document produced by a Czech company hat supplies heat to blocks of accommodation. It compares the product with softening water, a mainstream alternative. The main financial savings were due to reduced water and salt use.


UPDATES/ ADDITIONS

One economic area that is becoming more prevalent, especially in areas with water shortages, is the direct economic benefit due to water savings. The next two studies, released since the initial grating of the label, illustrate this.

As an example of the installations on larger pipe sizes, “NE Power Stations” [4] describes two combined-cycle natural gas electricity generation plants. Hydroflow allowed these plants, which operate on municipal water, to operate at higher concentration levels without the scale problems that would occur at these levels without Hydroflow. This means less water needs to be discarded and replaced, saving huge amounts on both water and sewage costs. The action of removing biofilm allowed both plants to reduce their biocide chemicals as well as their scale and corrosion inhibitors. The first is a 500MW plant in the US Midwest with an 8-cell cooling tower system. Hydroflow allowed the conductivity to be increase from 1800 to 3150 microSiemens/cm, with cycles of concentration going from 5.5 to 9.7. This led to a reduction in blowdown (discarded) water of 48.6% (60 million gallons/yr). The second was a 700MW plant with a 10 cell cooling tower. This plant went from 200 to 4000 microSiemens/cm with cycles of concentration going from 3.0 to 6.0, saving  60% of blowdown water (200 million gallons/yr). Both plants were able to achieve over 70% chemical reduction. 

For a typical combined cycle plant, these reductions would save around $350,000 annually.

"Municipal Building Chillers" [12] shows an installation on a cooling tower. The conductivity of the tower was increased from 3000 to 7000 microSiemens/cm. At the same time chemical use was almost completely discontinued. After 5 1/2 months the chiller was inspected and found to have minimal deposits. The treatment by Hydroflow led to a 68% reduction in water and sewage costs (blowdown), an almost 100% decrease in chemical costs and an unspecified reduction due to ease of maintenance.
ssf.economic_intensity_detail:
Solution uses minimal energy, less than 20W. This translates into around £20 worth of electricity per year. 
There are no consumables or replacements needed, so electricity is the only ongoing costs.
Over a 20year lifespan this is still less than the cost of a typical unit.
ssf.ef_total_cost_1: Annual saving on water and electricity of $73,000 [example, ref 7] compared to mainstream alternative
ssf.ef_total_cost_2: Annual saving on chemical treatment of $13, 000 [example, ref 7] compared to mainstream alternative

Goals included reducing water and sewage usage, chemical consumption, energy and maintenance needs, and extending equipment life. implementationstories.description_result: The HydroFLOW unit prevented limescale and biofouling in chillers and cooling towers, boosting efficiency and enabling higher water reuse. Environmental benefits included 85% less discharge water, 75% fewer chemicals, and 50% less maintenance. Energy use dropped 10%. Economically, the system saved $73,400 annually in water and energy, with a positive Net Present Value of $4.76M over the building’s 50-year lifespan, highlighting strong environmental and financial returns.

solutions_of_the_month.one_sentence_description: An ecological, cost-effective hull cover preventing fouling and eliminating toxic paints
solutions_of_the_month.intro: K-Ren is a young impact-driven company offering an ecological solution to protect boat hulls without resorting to toxic antifouling paints. Our cover, manufactured in France from recyclable technical fabrics, blocks out light and prevents the growth of marine organisms, thereby avoiding the release of heavy metals and biocides into the environment. Easy to install and suitable for all types of vessels, it reduces the need for frequent hull maintenance while preserving biodiversity and nautical performance. Committed to local and responsible production, we collaborate with regional partners and constantly verify the safety of our materials. K-Ren provides a concrete alternative to traditional hull cleaning, combining performance, sustainability, and respect for the oceans to support the ecological transition of the maritime sector.
solutions_of_the_month.supporting: The K-REN hull cover, manufactured in France from recyclable technical fabrics, blocks out light and prevents the growth of marine organisms, thereby avoiding the release of heavy metals and biocides into the environment. Easy to install and suitable for all types of vessels, it reduces the need for frequent hull maintenance while preserving biodiversity and nautical performance. Committed to local and responsible production, we collaborate with regional partners and constantly verify the safety of our materials. K-Ren provides a concrete alternative to traditional hull cleaning, combining performance, sustainability, and respect for the oceans to support the ecological transition of the maritime sector.
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_1: No light, no fouling – Our SqualTeck® fabric blocks 100 % of sunlight around the hull. Without light, algae and shell-formers can’t start photosynthesis, so nothing accroaches and the boat stays perfectly clean
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_2: Quick fit, decade of use – A crew of two installs or removes a K-Ren cover in under 30 minutes while the boat stays afloat. The rugged, recyclable textile keeps its anti-fouling performance for roughly ten years, slashing maintenance stops
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_3: Zero toxins, real savings – Replacing antifouling paint, one cover prevents up to 150 kg of heavy-metal paint waste over its life and cuts hull drag. Owners save 5-10 % on fuel or gain the same margin of sailing speed, reducing CO₂ emissions
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_4: Each K-Ren cover eliminates 10 years of antifouling paint use: that’s 25 kg of copper and 400 kg CO₂e avoided per boat—equivalent to driving 2 000 km by car—and zero toxic discharge into the harbor
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_5: By eliminating the annual haul-out, a single covered boat saves ≥ 6 000 L of fresh water over 10 years—the daily domestic water needs of 40 people for one day
solutions_of_the_month.profitability_1: The K‑Ren cover pays for itself in 18 months on a 12 m monohull yacht, in 12 months on a catamaran—where haul‑outs are especially complex—and almost instantly on a FREMM frigate, thanks to 30 % fuel savings plus avoided maintenance

ssf.other_pool_restriction: We request that anyone involved in marketing antifouling paints be excluded from the expert jury.
ssf.name: Eco antifouling : K-Ren covers
ssf.one_sentence_description: An ecological, cost-effective hull cover preventing fouling and eliminating toxic paints.
ssf.public_short_description: K-Ren is a young impact-driven company offering an ecological solution to protect boat hulls without resorting to toxic antifouling paints. Our cover, manufactured in France from recyclable technical fabrics, blocks out light and prevents the growth of marine organisms, thereby avoiding the release of heavy metals and biocides into the environment. Easy to install and suitable for all types of vessels, it reduces the need for frequent hull maintenance while preserving biodiversity and nautical performance. Committed to local and responsible production, we collaborate with regional partners and constantly verify the safety of our materials. K-Ren provides a concrete alternative to traditional hull cleaning, combining performance, sustainability, and respect for the oceans to support the ecological transition of the maritime sector.
ssf.environmental_benefit: K-Ren eliminates the need for toxic antifouling paints, which release heavy metals and microplastics into marine ecosystems. By using an opaque cover made from recyclable materials, it blocks light to prevent fouling without discharging harmful substances. This system reduces freshwater consumption by limiting the frequency of high-pressure cleanings, and it cuts down on hazardous waste generation from hull maintenance. By stopping organisms from settling on the hull, K-Ren also curbs the spread of invasive species. Durable and reusable over multiple seasons, the cover protects both vessel performance and biodiversity. Locally manufactured, it reduces logistics-related carbon emissions. In doing so, K-Ren contributes to preserving oceans while aligning with increasingly stringent environmental standards.
ssf.economical_benefit: K-Ren offers numerous economic benefits for both boat owners and larger submerged structures. By eliminating the use of antifouling paints—which require frequent reapplications and generate hazardous waste—our solution significantly reduces operating costs, even for large-scale underwater installations. Users spend less time and money hauling out hulls or structures, sanding, and repainting. Freed from regular cleaning, they also save on freshwater and labor. A protected surface reduces drag, cutting fuel consumption for motorboats and improving speed for sailboats. Its low-tech design and local production help keep acquisition costs manageable, while the system’s durability allows reuse over multiple seasons. For marinas, K-Ren considerably lowers the amount of waste to process, thus reducing related management expenses. In this way, K-Ren combines cost-effectiveness and environmental responsibility,  meeting evolving regulations, and ensuring a swift return on investment.
ssf.ss_title: Protection of a multi-mission frigate for one month, hull cleaning without toxic antifouling
ssf.ss_description: In August 2023, K-Ren deployed its floating hull protection system on a FREMM (multi-mission frigate) in Toulon for a one-month test. The system, designed to block light and prevent photosynthesis, was installed without antifouling paints or chemicals. Despite the high sea temperatures at this time of year, which usually accelerate fouling development, the protected hull showed a noticeable reduction in marine growth compared to untreated areas. The results were confirmed through an official technical analysis, currently confidential. This test, conducted with the French Navy, demonstrates the potential of our solution for large military and industrial vessels requiring non-invasive, effective antifouling alternatives.
ssf.ss_case_study_impact: The FREMM frigate, equipped for one month, avoided toxic antifouling paints, heavy-metal and microplastic discharges, and reduced freshwater usage for cleaning. A cleaner hull lowers fuel consumption (up to 20%) and CO₂ emissions. For such large vessels, the return on investment is immediate, given the high costs and mandatory nature of dry-dock maintenance.
ssf.ss_grants_recognition: In 2023, we discovered our cover also acts curatively: once installed on a fouled hull, blocking light starves organisms and cleans the surface. This finding attracted local grants and acknowledgments, expanding our funding prospects. We received support from regional innovation programs recognizing our solution’s ability to prevent toxic discharges and microplastics, further validating the broader environmental benefit of K-Ren.
ssf.technical_aspects:
K-Ren’s solution is built around a major technological principle: blocking light to prevent photosynthesis and, consequently, the attachment of marine organisms (algae, barnacles, etc.) to a vessel’s hull. We use a high-tech opaque fabric, developed after many years of R&D, combining flexibility, mechanical strength, and environmental safety.
1. Operating Principle

    Light Blockage: The cover wraps around the submerged hull area, creating total darkness. Marine organisms requiring light to grow cannot thrive.

    No Biocides or Toxic Paint: Unlike traditional antifouling paints, our system doesn’t rely on heavy metals or chemicals, thus eliminating metal or microplastic discharges.

    Preventive and Curative Effect: The opaque fabric not only stops new growth (preventive) but also weakens any existing organisms, which die off due to lack of light (curative).

2. Technical Characteristics

    Fabric Composition: At the core of K-Ren is a multi-layer textile with an anti-adhesive coating, ensuring total opacity and mechanical durability for underwater conditions.

    Mechanical Strength: Key areas (rudders, propellers, keels, etc.) can be reinforced depending on the vessel’s shape and size.

    Innocuity Tests: Laboratory analyses confirm no toxic particle migration into the water, even after extended immersion.

    Adaptability: Each cover is custom-designed, factoring in appendages (fixed keel, lifting keel, jets, etc.) and hull types (monohull, multihull, outboard).

3. Installation and Usage

    Setup: Delivered folded in a carrying bag, the system typically takes under 30 minutes to install for a medium-sized sailboat.

    Securing and Mooring: Straps or dedicated lines ensure a snug fit around the hull, maintaining total darkness.

    Removal: Once the boat goes out to sea, the cover is simply folded and stored onboard or on the dock. Certain “semi-submerged” versions (e.g., Zendock) stay partially in place for easier handling.

4. Technical Documents and IP

    Lab Tests: Technical reports on tensile and abrasion resistance, as well as spectral opacity (e.g., TR-2024-KR).

    Field Trials: We have tested and validated the system for many years, with over 250 boats already equipped, multiple institutional collaborations (Navy, shipyards), and well-known skippers like Michel Desjoyeaux.

    Safety Reports: In vitro analyses show no organic or metallic compounds are released into the water (available upon request).

    Intellectual Property: We have applied for a patent covering the multi-layer fabric and its assembly method, and continue R&D to enhance the anti-adhesive coating.

5. Type of Technology

K-Ren is essentially a low-tech solution relying on cutting-edge materials. This “low-tech / high-performance” approach offers:

    Ease of Use: No heavy infrastructure or electrical setup needed.

    Simple Transport and Maintenance: The cover folds up compactly.

    Effortless Deployment: The boat remains afloat, with no hoists or dry docks required.

6. Potential Developments

    IoT Integration: We plan to embed sensors (temperature, currents, fouling level) to gather environmental data (ongoing R&D).

    Extensions to Other Infrastructures: Offshore wind turbines, tidal devices, connected buoys.

    Floating Stations: Our “Zendock” version acts like a mobile dock where the hull can slot in, avoiding repeated cover handling.

7. Conclusion

K-Ren’s operation hinges on a straightforward yet highly effective principle: block light rather than deploying chemical products. The result: fouling is eliminated, toxic waste is minimized, water consumption is reduced, and installation is hassle-free. Tested and validated for many years, with over 250 vessels already equipped, our technology demonstrates its reliability and capability to sustainably reshape maritime maintenance.
ssf.human_assets:
K-Ren’s expertise centers on a core group of in-house specialists. Bernard Doriez, an international expert in textile architecture (formerly with Toile et Structures and DBI), designed the multi-layer fabric after more than thirty years of R&D and industrial innovation. Lucie Doriez, the company’s founder, brings project management and impact entrepreneurship experience, overseeing partnerships and overall strategy.

To complement this foundation, we rely on diverse specialized profiles: textile engineers, field technicians, and former offshore racing skippers who rigorously test the solution in real-world maritime conditions, refining prototypes and ensuring practical applicability. For validation, K-Ren collaborates with specialized laboratories to check for any potential particle migration, and we conduct extensive field trials with recreational boaters, professional sailors, and the French Navy.

In terms of networking, K-Ren benefits from the support of regional competitiveness clusters and incubators focused on eco-innovation, providing strategic guidance and connecting us with maritime experts, funders, and shipyards. We also maintain close dialogue with environmentally conscious ports that help us fine-tune our service offerings—ranging from rental programs to installation and removal options.

This combination of in-house expertise and external partnerships—engineers, navigators, laboratories, and institutional networks—drives K-Ren’s mission to revolutionize hull maintenance with a solution free from both biocides and heavy metals.
ssf.external_threats:
The global antifouling market is worth €66 bn per year (TAM). The portion we can serve immediately—vessels ≤ 30 m and early offshore assets—totals €25 bn per year (SAM). By 2030, we aim to capture 0.05 % of that volume, i.e. 10 000 K‑Ren Covers deployed annually, generating €12 m in recurring revenue (average basket €2000). This scenario assumes uptake by 0.03 % of the world fleet, driven by ISO 18725 and the ongoing biocide phase‑out.

Supply chain. SqualTeck® fabric is woven and coated solely at DIATEX in Lyon (OEKO‑TEX 100, ISO 14001). We are filing a joint patent with DIATEX, securing exclusivity and strong barriers to entry. High‑tenacity ropes come from Cousin Trestec in Brittany; 316 L fittings from SMEs in Saint‑Étienne. With over one million m² of annual capacity, DIATEX can easily match our ramp‑up; the other components scale without bottlenecks.

Capacity & ramp‑up. K‑Ren Lab in Montpellier currently outputs 300 covers per year with six staff. Adding HF welders and eight operators lifts internal capacity to 1 500 units in 2025. Two partner workshops (Basque Country, Var), sourced via Bernard Doriez’s textile network, will contribute 3 500 units with no heavy CAPEX. A manufacturing‑distribution licence in New Caledonia will supply the Pacific (1 000 units/yr). By end‑2026 total capacity reaches 6 000 covers/yr; duplicating the workshop‑plus‑licence model scales us to 10 000/yr before 2030.

Go‑to‑market.

European (2024‑26): e‑commerce, chandlers, boat shows and sailor ambassadors, reinforced by an 18‑month rent‑to‑own plan.

Tropical regions (2025‑28): licences in Australia/New Caledonia (8 % royalty).

Professional verticals: framework deals with marinas for ISO 18725 compliance, followed by offshore pilots with Naval Group and EDF Renewables.

Recurring services: subscription packages for handling, inspections and end‑of‑life recycling.

Proprietary textile, a short European supply chain and a licence‑plus‑service model give K‑Ren a scalable an
ssf.mainstream_alternative: The mainstream reference is annual toxic antifouling paint: about 90 % of boat owners and marine operators still coat hulls with copper- and biocide-based paints to curb biofouling. This process requires yearly haul-out, high-pressure stripping and repainting, produces ≈ 20 000 t of hazardous waste per year in France alone, consumes large volumes of freshwater, and costs on average €2 000–€10 000 per vessel.
ssf.business_opportunity:
Competing approaches on the market
1. “Eco-friendly” paints without copper – copper is replaced by silicone or silica additives, yet the film remains a chemical layer that must be renewed every season. Cost : €2 000–€8 000 / yr for a 12 m yacht; hazardous waste is unchanged.
2. Silicone foul-release coatings – excellent on offshore racing boats but require controlled-atmosphere spraying, an epoxy primer and strict climatic windows; initial cost > €25 / m² and full re-application every 4-5 years.
3. Ultrasonic systems – 40–80 W devices bonded inside the hull; effective mainly on rigid GRP/alu hulls, no protection for appendages. Installed cost €2 500–€5 000 plus annual servicing.
4. Robotic or fixed boat-wash stations – mechanical cleaning at the dock; CAPEX €150 k–€400 k for the marina, high energy & water use, mandatory sludge collection; no protection between cleans.
5. Rigid / inflatable floating docks – keep the hull out of the water but cost > €20 000 for a 10 m boat, occupy large berths, add weight and require pumps; unsuitable for bow-to-quay berths and congested marinas.
How K-Ren stands apart : SqualTek® composite fabric – opaque, anti-adhesive, biomimetic coating developed in Lyon; blocks photosynthesis and proven non-leaching (IFREMER tests).Zero chemicals, zero energy, zero discharge – purely passive prevention; also curative (FREMM frigate test : fouling vanished in 30 days).
    Universal fit – bespoke 3-D design for yachts, powerboats, multihulls, offshore floats, FPSO chains… Deploys or folds in < 30 min without heavy gear.Long life & circularity – service life ≥ 10 years, fully recyclable via the Texyloop® textile loop.Competitive economics – average ticket €3 000 (same for Zendock station); ROI < 24 months by eliminating paint, haul-outs and cutting fuel 5–10 %.Scalable production – in-house digital cutting & sewing in Mauguio, plus licensed manufacture for export (New Caledonia, Caribbean).
ssf.status:
Scale-up strategy
1. Demand-driven production
• Mauguio Lab (1 CNC + 15 sewing stations) delivers up to 4 000 covers / year.
• 2026 : second line + automated finishing (CAPEX < €600 k via lease).
• Licensed hubs (quality audited by K-Ren) lower freight CO₂ and duties: New Caledonia active, Caribbean 2025, Scandinavia 2026.

2. Interlocking sales channels
• Chandlers – national frames with Accastillage Diffusion & Uship (> 350 EU stores) for diagnosis, sales and first-level after-sales.
• Yard / OEM – Outremer, Catana, Excess, Neel… “green performance” option on new builds (already 40 % of 2024 turnover).
• Marinas – “Clean Port” leasing packages fully ISO 18725 compliant; 12 pilot ports, 40 targeted within three years.
• Premium conciergeries – turn-key cover handling → high recurrence and loyalty.

3. Institutional & offshore markets
• French Navy – FREMM POC approved, fleet tender 2025-26.
• Floating wind – MoU with EDF Renouvelables & Ocean Winds for chain and floater sleeves → rollout 2027.
• Aquaculture & tuna seiners – Ifremer study (24 000 m² of fabric, > €40 M TAM).

4. Network effects & differentiation
• Flagship ambassadors (Desjoyeaux, Caudrelier) + FFVoile partnership create strong social proof.
• IoT platform: fleet monitoring, maintenance alerts, ESG reports for ports and ship-owners → drives upsell (Zendock®, rudder socks).
• “Hull Impact Certificate” quantifies CO₂ & fuel savings, easing access to green grants and sustainable finance.

5. Funding & ramp-up
• Series A €1 M – closing 2025 : double EU sales force, launch Offshore BU, secure technical-fabric stocks.
• Public leverage : Bpifrance Eco-Energy loans, ADEME grants, Horizon Europe circular-textile calls.

Summary
Our hybrid model—agile in-house manufacturing, licensed satellites, and a dense partner network—enables global scale-up at low capital intensity while preserving margins and unlocking high-value industrial segments.
ssf.summary_market_of_application: No light, no fouling – Our SqualTeck® fabric blocks 100 % of sunlight around the hull. Without light, algae and shell-formers can’t start photosynthesis, so nothing accroaches and the boat stays perfectly clean.
ssf.summary_market_of_application_2: Quick fit, decade of use – A crew of two installs or removes a K-Ren cover in under 30 minutes while the boat stays afloat. The rugged, recyclable textile keeps its anti-fouling performance for roughly ten years, slashing maintenance stops.
ssf.summary_market_of_application_3: Zero toxins, real savings – Replacing antifouling paint, one cover prevents up to 150 kg of heavy-metal paint waste over its life and cuts hull drag. Owners save 5-10 % on fuel or gain the same margin of sailing speed, reducing CO₂ emissions.
ssf.sei_case_study_description:
A 12 m polyester sailing yacht (surface below waterline ≈ 40 m²) berthed year-round in a Mediterranean marina. Like 94 % of similar boats, it is normally protected each season with a self-polishing copper-based antifouling paint.Mainstream alternative: yearly antifouling cycle Step	Environmental load*
1. Haul-out, HP-wash	600 L fresh water, 8 kWh electricity
2. Sanding / stripping	15 kg paint dust & chips containing ≈ 6 kg Cu/Zn, 0.5 kg biocides
3. Re-painting (2 coats)	30 kg wet paint → 12 kg dry residue; 57 kg CO₂-eq for production & transport
4. Season at sea	3–5 % drag ↑ → +120 L diesel (≈ 320 kg CO₂-eq)
5. Waste treatment	Paint sludge sent to hazardous landfill (15 kg)
*Figures from French Eco-Naviguer study, EU Biocide dossier 2023, and IMO fuel-drag curves.
K-Ren Solution: opaque protective cover
Step	Environmental load
1. In-water installation (2 crew, 30 min)	No haul-out, no fresh water, no electricity
2. Use phase (10 years)	Zero biocide release; hull remains clean, so fuel use unchanged (sail) or –5 % (motor)
3. Maintenance	Rinse once a year with harbour hose (< 50 L)
4. End-of-life	Cover (≈ 18 kg PU/polyester) sent to Texyloop®, 95 % material recycled, 5 % energy recovery
Impact comparison for one season

Heavy-metal & biocide discharge: –100 % (≈ 6 kg avoided)
Hazardous solid waste: –100 % (≈ 15 kg avoided)
Fresh-water consumption: –92 % (600 L → 50 L)
Fuel & CO₂ (auxiliary engine or motor-sail use): –120 L diesel / –320 kg CO₂-eq if motoring hours unchanged; more when drag reduction counted.
Energy & GHG in manufacturing: Cover production = 38 kg CO₂-eq (one-off). Over its 10-year life the cumulative footprint is > 80 % lower than 10 paint cycles.
For the representative 12 m yacht, adopting one K-Ren cover eliminates ~60 kg of toxic residues and 3.2 t CO₂-eq over a decade, while saving 6 000 L of fresh water and cutting operating costs. The concept is thus net-positive and scalable to > 33 million leisure boats worldwide.
ssf.sei_production_phase:
Case study : 12 m polyester sailing-yacht – 40 m² wetted surface (1 season)
Our Solution – K-Ren Protect cover
Item	Main materials	Weight
Squaltek® fabric (110 g/m² PET scrim + 220 g/m² PU opaque coating)	PET : 4.4 kg • PU : 8.8 kg	13.2 kg
Reinforcements & hardware	PET/PU tapes : 1.5 kg • Dyneema® thread : 0.08 kg • 316 L SS eyelets & clips : 3 kg	4.6 kg
Packaging (recycled cardboard)	0.6 kg	0.6 kg

Total cover weight : 18.4 kg.
Manufacturing energy : CNC cutting + stitching ≈ 0.35 kWh m-² → 15 kWh (≈ 5 kg CO₂-eq with the French grid).
No solvents, no heavy metals. 95 % of the textile is mechanically/chemically recycled (Texyloop®), metal and Dyneema enter conventional recycling streams; 5 % used for energy recovery.
Mainstream alternative – annual antifouling cycle
Item	Materials	1-season mass
Antifouling paint (2 coats, 750 µm wet)	Acrylic resin 4.8 kg • Solvents/additives 13.2 kg (fully evaporated) • Cu₂O 6 kg • ZnO 2 kg • Biocides 0.5 kg	26.5 kg applied (12.1 kg solid left on hull)
Sanding & wash-off sludge	Same solids + 2 kg polyester dust	≈ 15 kg hazardous waste
HP washing water	Freshwater	600 L
Yard energy	HP washer + compressor	8 kWh

Paint production footprint : 1.9 kg CO₂-eq kg-¹ → ~57 kg CO₂-eq per season.
~10 kg VOCs released to air. Sludge sent to special-waste landfill.
Season-by-season comparison
	K-Ren cover	Antifouling
Virgin material	18.4 kg (fully recyclable)	26.5 kg (toxic)
Heavy metals/biocides	0 kg	8 kg Cu/Zn + 0.5 kg organics
Fresh water used	50 L (rinse)	600 L
Manufacturing / yard energy	15 kWh	8 kWh yard + ~160 kWh equiv. in paint production
Hazardous waste	0 kg	≈ 15 kg sludge ISDD

Bottom-line : one K-Ren cover replaces >25 kg of toxic paint with <20 kg of recyclable materials, eliminates heavy-metal discharge, cuts water use by a factor 12, and shrinks energy & CO₂ footprint by roughly 70 %.
ssf.sei_transport:
Supply Chain & Logistics – K-Ren SqualTeck® Covers

Our proprietary SqualTeck® fabric is woven and coated by DIATEX (Lyon, France), a mid-size mill holding OEKO-TEX® Standard 100 and ISO 14001 certification. The yarn blend is 60 % post-consumer recycled PET and 40 % virgin PET to guarantee mechanical strength. Finished rolls (≈ 35 kg each) are consolidated weekly and trucked 305 km to our K-Ren Lab in Mauguio (Occitanie) on EURO 6 vehicles operating with > 90 % load factors.
Upstream transport

    90 % of incoming tonnage travels less than 400 km.
    No air freight.

In-house production

Cutting (CNC), 3-D form-finding and sewing are carried out in a single facility powered by 100 % renewable electricity (Enercoop contract). Off-cuts under 20 cm are shredded on site and reused as stuffing for fenders or packaging, achieving < 2 % material loss.
Downstream logistics

    Overseas shipments (Americas, Australia, Pacific): packed flat in reusable crates and sent by ocean freight through Clean Cargo-member lines; average transport footprint < 9 g CO₂-eq per tonne-km.

Circular end-of-life route

Real-world monitoring since 2005 shows a ≥ 10-year service life per cover. When a cover reaches end-of-life, the owner downloads a prepaid label and sends it back to K-Ren. We forward the material to PLAXTIL (Bordeaux), where it is mechanically ground, the PU coating is separated, and both streams are remelted into recycled pellets for street furniture and reusable logistics trays. The process yields a 92 % recycling rate and avoids landfill or incineration.
Net effect

By sourcing, manufacturing and recycling entirely within France, we minimise transport emissions and ensure full traceability.
ssf.sei_use_phase:
Resource Consumption – Use Phase

Case study : 12 m cruising sailboat berthed year-round in the Mediterranean
Item	Mainstream : antifouling paint + yearly haul-out	K-Ren Protect cover
Fresh-water	High-pressure wash after haul-out ≈ 600 L/yr ¹ + spot rinses ≈ 100 L/yr	Monthly hose-down of cover ≈ 50 L×12 = 600 L/yr — carried out on the quay, 0 L released to the sea
Electricity	Hoist & travel-lift 15 kWh/yr, HP washer 6 kWh/yr	Manual handling; optional air-blow 0.5 kWh/yr
Raw materials	2 coats hard-matrix antifouling 10 L (≈ 15 kg)/yr + disposables 1.5 kg/yr	No paint for 10 yrs → 0 kg/yr; minor grease for zip < 50 g/yr
Fuel overspend	Fouling ⇒ +10 % drag → aux engine 200 h @ 5 L/h = 100 L diesel/yr → ≈ 267 kg CO₂/yr	Clean hull → 0 L extra fuel

¹ Université Bretagne Sud “Éconaviguer” survey, 134 French marinas (2022).
Comparative results

    Water: 600 L toxic wash water avoided each year; cover rinse uses non-potable dock supply.

    Energy: net saving ≈ 20 kWh/yr (≈ 2 % of a French household).

    Materials: eliminates 15 kg paint/yr containing copper, zinc & biocides, plus contaminated disposables.

    Fuel/CO₂: saves 100 L diesel & 0.27 t CO₂-eq/yr through constant clean hull.

Over the 10-year lifespan of one K-Ren cover this equals :

    6 000 L fresh water not polluted,

    150 kg toxic coatings avoided,

    200 kWh electricity saved,

    1 000 L diesel and 2.7 t CO₂-eq prevented.

By turning an annual, resource-intensive haul-out into a light monthly rinse, the K-Ren solution nearly eliminates operational resource use while stopping the chronic release of heavy metals and biocides into the marine environment.
ssf.sei_disposal_phase:
At the end of its 8- to 10-year service life, every K-Ren cover follows a closed-loop pathway created in 2024:

    Mandatory take-back
    Owners receive prepaid labels; dealers collect returned covers with their normal pallet flow—zero extra tonne-kilometres.

    Selective dismantling
    In a local ESAT social-enterprise workshop the cover is split into Squalteck® textile, acetal zips, and stainless-steel fittings.

    Material recovery
    Textile → PLAXTIL (Bordeaux): shredded, mixed with a bio-sourced binder, re-extruded into pellets or boards re-sold to the marine industry (racks, deck panels). Yield > 90 %.
    Stainless steel → regional scrap recycler, melted and reused indefinitely.
    Acetal plastics → Occitanie loop (RecyOuest) for depolymerisation into virgin-grade granules (~80 % yield).

    Energy recovery
    The residual 2–3 % (PU dust, trims) feeds the Lunel waste-to-energy plant, whose steam supplies the local district network.

    Traceability & results
    Each batch bears a QR code linked to its digital bill of materials; masses in/out are logged in our ERP and reported annually to ADEME. Pilot flows 2023-24 deliver 97 % material valorisation (78 % closed-loop), 3 % energy, 0 % landfill.

    Absence of ecotoxicity
    Independent laboratory Plastic@Sea performed leaching tests: Cu, Zn, biocides < 0.1 ppm. Unlike antifouling paint sludge (rich in heavy metals and biocides, sent to hazardous-waste landfills), the K-Ren stream generates no dangerous fraction.

Summary: mandatory return, local dismantling, high-yield recycling and energy valorisation create a truly circular end-of-life while eliminating toxic residues and supporting inclusive employment—all with traceable, audited data.
ssf.ei_biodiversity_1: Each K-Ren cover eliminates 10 years of antifouling paint use: that’s 25 kg of copper and 400 kg CO₂e avoided per boat—equivalent to driving 2 000 km by car—and zero toxic discharge into the harbor.
ssf.ei_water_savings_1: By eliminating the annual haul-out, a single covered boat saves ≥ 6 000 L of fresh water over 10 years—the daily domestic water needs of 40 people for one day.
ssf.economic:
Economic Incentives for the Client & Comparison with the Mainstream Alternative

1. Up-front Investment

    K-Ren Protect (cover): ~€3,000 excl. tax for a 12 m sailboat (20 m² hull).

    ZenDock® (floating cradle): ~€3,000 excl. tax, one-time installation, no annual handling.

    Conventional antifouling + haul-out:

        Haul-out & hull cleaning: €1,000

        Labor (sanding, prep): €800

        Antifouling paint: €1,200

        Total annual cost: €3,000

2. Frequency & Maintenance

    Mainstream: Annual (often biannual) haul-outs, complex logistics (scheduling, dry dock), ~600 L freshwater per operation.

    K-Ren Protect: Crew installs/removes in <30 min, no haul-out, no chemical maintenance, cover lifespan ~10 years.

    ZenDock®: Cradle remains in place, no annual intervention, <1 h initial setup.

3. Direct Savings Over Time
Year	Antifouling & Haul-out (cumulative)	K-Ren Protect (cumulative)	ZenDock® (cumulative)	Cumulative Savings vs Mainstream
1	€3 000	€3 000	€3 000	€0
2	€6 000	€3 000	€3 000	€3 000
3	€9 000	€3 000	€3 000	€6 000
…	…	€3 000	€3 000	Linear growth

    ROI & Payback:

        Covers & Cradle: breakeven by Year 2 (savings ≥ initial cost).

        Antifouling: ongoing expense, no asset value.

4. Indirect Savings

    Fuel: Clean hull reduces drag, saving up to 5 % fuel (e.g. a vessel spending €10 000/year saves €500/year).

    Time & Logistics: Eliminates dry-dock planning; crew time valued at €40/h, saving ~10 h/year = €400/year.

    Water: Avoids 600 L freshwater/year (€4/m³ = €2.40/year).

    Waste: Avoids 15 g biocide/m²/year (20 m² = 300 g/year), at €200/ton treatment = €60/year.

5. Detailed Case Study (12 m Sailboat, 20 m² Hull)

    Conventional: €15 000 over 5 years.

    K-Ren Protect: €3 000 one-off, no further costs for 10 years.

    ZenDock®: €3 000 one-off.

    Gross Savings: >€12 000 over 5 years.

    Net Savings (including fuel, time): >€14 000 over 5 years.

6. Methodology & Sources

    Pricing from 2023 Mediterranean ports survey (EcoNaviguer, UBS).

    Fuel & water savings validated by K-Ren user survey (n=50).

    Waste treatment costs from Port of Marseille (2024 rate schedule).

    Annex: Excel file “Case_12m_KRen_vs_HaulOut.xlsx” details cost lines, cash-flow projections, ROI & payback calculations.
ssf.economic_intensity_detail:
For the K-Ren Protect cover (and similarly for the ZenDock cradle), the vast majority of costs are incurred up-front at purchase and installation, with very low ongoing operating expenses over the product’s life:

    Initial investment

        K-Ren Protect: ~€3 000 HT for a 12 m hull (20 m²).

        ZenDock®: ~€3 000 HT for a floating cradle custom-fitted to the boat.

    Operating costs over 10 years

        Installation/removal labor: 30 min each time by crew → ~€40/h rate → ~€400 total (10 years × 1 h/year).

        Storage / light cleaning: negligible (<€100 over 10 years).

        No chemical, haul-out or freshwater costs.

    Total cost of ownership (TCO) over 10 years

        Capital cost: €3 000 HT

        OPEX: ~€500–€600 HT

        TCO: ~€3 600 HT

    Capital intensity
    Capital  costTCO≈30003600≈83%(K-Ren Protect, 10-year lifespan)
    TCOCapitalcost​≈36003000​≈83%(K-Ren Protect, 10-year lifespan)

    Even more conservatively, if crew install/remove twice per year (2 h total/y), OPEX rises to ~€800 over 10 years, making capital intensity still > 80%. For ZenDock®, zero annual handling reduces OPEX further, pushing capital intensity > 85%.

Conclusion
K-Ren’s solutions are highly capital-intensive (over 80% of TCO at installation) with minimal operating costs. This contrasts sharply with conventional antifouling, where > 95% of costs recur annually (haul-out, paint, labor, water, waste treatment), giving K-Ren a clear economic advantage over the vessel’s service life.
ssf.ef_total_cost_1: K-Ren Protect blocks sunlight to stop biofouling without toxic paints: each m² of cover avoids releasing 15 g of biocide, which would otherwise pollute 10 000 m³ of seawater.
ssf.ef_total_cost_2: The K‑Ren cover pays for itself in 18 months on a 12 m monohull yacht, in 12 months on a catamaran—where haul‑outs are especially complex—and almost instantly on a FREMM frigate, thanks to 30 % fuel savings plus avoided maintenance.

implementationstories.title: Protection of a multi-mission frigate for one month, hull cleaning without toxic antifouling
implementationstories.description_client: In August 2023, K-Ren deployed its floating hull protection system on a FREMM (multi-mission frigate) in Toulon for a one-month test. The system, designed to block light and prevent photosynthesis, was installed without antifouling paints or chemicals. Despite the high sea temperatures at this time of year, which usually accelerate fouling development, the protected hull showed a noticeable reduction in marine growth compared to untreated areas. The results were confirmed through an official technical analysis, currently confidential. This test, conducted with the French Navy, demonstrates the potential of our solution for large military and industrial vessels requiring non-invasive, effective antifouling alternatives.
implementationstories.description_result: The FREMM frigate, equipped for one month, avoided toxic antifouling paints, heavy-metal and microplastic discharges, and reduced freshwater usage for cleaning. A cleaner hull lowers fuel consumption (up to 20%) and CO₂ emissions. For such large vessels, the return on investment is immediate, given the high costs and mandatory nature of dry-dock maintenance.

implementationstories.title: Michel Desjoyeaux’s Catamaran: One-Hull Test Reveals Zero Fouling with K-Ren.
implementationstories.description_client: Michel Desjoyeaux, a world-renowned offshore racer, decided to test K-Ren’s light-blocking cover on just one hull of his catamaran “Mer Agitée,” leaving the other hull unprotected for comparison. Over the span of one month, the results were striking: the protected hull remained free of algae and other marine growth, while the unprotected hull accumulated a significant layer of fouling. Michel was impressed by how effectively the cover inhibited fouling without relying on toxic paints or frequent cleaning. According to his feedback, the procedure was straightforward to install and required minimal maintenance, which saved both time and effort. This one-hull “A/B test” underscores K-Ren’s ability to replace chemical antifouling methods, offering a practical and eco-friendly solution for top-level sailors and everyday boaters alike.
implementationstories.description_result: Michel Desjoyeaux’s one-month catamaran test showed zero fouling on the protected hull: no toxic paints, no metal or microplastic releases, and reduced water usage. Fuel savings from 5–10% less drag lowered CO₂. Freed from repainting, users see immediate cost reductions with a quick ROI, typically within one or two antifouling cycles.

solutions_of_the_month.one_sentence_description: A solution for organizations seeking to accelerate their energy transition through their real estate energy potential
solutions_of_the_month.supporting: vadiMAP means "moving on to green with My Advanced Power". The purpose of the vadiMAP solution is to get the optimal renewable energy system in order to optimize the potential of your buildings in their geographic, energy and operational context. Based on a user-friendly online platform, vadiMAP allows building owners to save energy costs, to gain autonomy and reach carbon neutrality. The process starts with a comprehensive online questionnaire to collect the data needed to deliver a one-of-a-kind prescription report by which you can start making well-informed decisions. The turnkey process continues until the optimal renewable energy system is turned on with the expected results. For building owners, vadiMAP makes it possible to create an energy transition plan for a fraction of the time and costs in comparison with by traditional firms. Whether you own/operate one or thousands of buildings for your organization and look for a simple transition plan, vadiMAP is your solution.

solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_2: Up to one (1) megawatt energy systems, any building connected to the electrical grid now has three options: status quo, self-generation or hybrid (vadiMAP will figure it out)
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_3: Energy professionals and utilities (electric and gas) are now asking for their own SaaS instance of vadiMAP, hence this is a strategic offering for them in 2026
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_4: Per the GHG protocol, vadiMAP can reduce up to 100% of direct CO2 emissions (e.g. full replacement of a diesel generator) and tens/hundreds of tons of CO2 of indirect emissions (e.g. fossil-based generation from the main grid)
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_5: To displace 7.1 gigatons of carbon dioxide-equivalent, 10% of all buildings (C&I) will be equipped with a system to generate electricity one-site by 2050
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_6: In a vadiMAP Prescription for a greenhouse, the solar PV system recommended was ground-mounted with a 120kW installed power. Annually, it generates 30% of the energy needs, $ 29,700 of savings and a reduction of 19 tCO2e, for a 10-year payback period
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_7: All vadiMAP Prescriptions contain a clear computation of GHG emissions with and without the measures best meeting the operational needs of each building

guidesectors.name: Buildings & Constructions
guidesectors.definition: Solutions related to the design, construction, operation, and maintenance of physical structures including residential, commercial, and industrial buildings. The Solutions in this sector aim to promote sustainability and efficiency in the construction and building industry, addressing challenges and innovating across the entire lifecycle of structures.

guidesectors.name: Utilities (Water, Energy, Waste)
guidesectors.definition: Solutions that allow for the comprehensive planning, coordination, and optimization of essential services related to water, energy, and waste. This sector involves the responsible and efficient provision, distribution, and management of these critical resources to support societal functions and ensure sustainable practices. It includes water management (sourcing, treatment, distribution), energy management (generation, storage, distribution) and waste management (collection, recycling, and treatment).

guidesectors.name: Mobility
guidesectors.definition: Solutions that involve the movement of people and goods, encompassing various modes of transportation. This includes both public and private transportation systems, along with the infrastructure that supports them, such as roads, railways, airports, and ports.

ssf.outcum_text: MA 31/07/25 - Send the ASR to Marc Antoine
ssf.name: vadiMAP is the Solution's Official Name
ssf.one_sentence_description: Accelerating the energy transition by harnessing the untapped power of real estate energy.
ssf.public_short_description: vadiMAP means "moving on to green with My Advanced Power". The purpose of the vadiMAP solution is to get the optimal renewable energy system in order to optimize the potential of your buildings in their geographic, energy and operational context. Based on a user-friendly online platform, vadiMAP allows building owners to save energy costs, to gain autonomy and reach carbon neutrality. The process starts with a comprehensive online questionnaire to collect the data needed to deliver a one-of-a-kind prescription report by which you can start making well-informed decisions. The turnkey process continues until the optimal renewable energy system is turned on with the expected results. For building owners, vadiMAP makes it possible to create an energy transition plan for a fraction of the time and costs in comparison with by traditional firms. Whether you own/operate one or thousands of buildings for your organization and look for a simple transition plan, vadiMAP is your solution.
ssf.environmental_benefit: At its core, vadiMAP is dedicated to making building portfolios more sustainable. Every deliverable—whether to clients or partners—carries embedded sustainability benefits, from enhanced energy performance to direct environmental responsibility.
ssf.economical_benefit: All vadiMAP Prescriptions reports, no exception, outlines economical benefits for the building owner/operator. That is made very clear with economic metrics such as CapEx/OpEx, ROI, payback, NPV, etc.
ssf.ss_client: More than 100 clients spread across 6 countries: e.g. Harnois, Maison Eureka, St-Hubert Restaurants, Toromont Cat, McDonald's, Desjardins, Enbridge, BMO Banking...
ssf.ss_title: Building operators with the will to leverage energy efficiency and renewables.
ssf.ss_case_study_impact: In the fall of 2020, vadiMAP completed a prescription for a greenhouse located in Ontario, whose heating and ventilation consume more than 700,000 kWh per year. In this case, the solar PV installation is ground-mounted with an installed power of 120 kW. Annually, it generates 30% of the energy needs, $ 29,700 of savings as well as a reduction of 19 tCO2e, for a payback period of 10 years.
ssf.technical_aspects:
The vadiMAP introduction deck presents the solution from the client’s perspective, illustrating how our platform guides users through each stage of the energy transition process. Central to our offering is the vadiMAP Prescription, a core deliverable that reflects our holistic and agnostic approach—meaning we assess the full energy potential of a building without bias toward specific technologies or suppliers.

The process begins with an online questionnaire, which captures the client’s priorities across three main long-term energy objectives: cost savings, energy autonomy, and emission reductions, with simulations over period of 25 years. As shown on slide 5, the process is iterative and flexible—clients can begin at any step, though it typically starts with prioritizing buildings within the portfolio.

The recommended technologies—referred to as “measures”—range from renewable energy systems to a wide array of energy efficiency solutions. Each recommendation is made on a building-by-building basis, informed by numerous technical factors including:
- A synthetic energy profile (a digital twin simulating 8,760 hours/year for electricity and gas),
- Weather conditions, physical characteristics, and operational constraints,
- As well as material and labor costs tailored to the selected measures.

To simplify the decarbonization journey for clients managing building portfolios, vadiMAP introduces a set of clear differentiators, highlighted on slide 7:
- Sensor-Free, Accurate & Fast Remote Assessment
- Energy Resilience to Climate Change
- Energy Efficiency & Renewables Integration
- Turnkey Execution through partnerships with EPC* partners for retrofit and conversion projects in the field within buildings.

Our intellectual property (IP) is embedded in proprietary AI models, advanced algorithms, and automated workflows, all designed to deliver a seamless and intuitive user experience. This is supported by extensive technical documentation maintained in Atlassian, covering thousands of pages.

See attached a high-level system architecture is also attached for your review.

* EPC: Engineering, Procurement & Construction
ssf.human_assets:
The vadiMAP R&D story started in 2016. It then became centric in 2018 so it was accelerated to manage the opportunity window. Currently in 2025 12 people are working full time on vadiMAP (plus 7 more part-time) with an aggressive plan to launch a vadiMAP SaaS (Solution as a Service) version of the solution by mid-year in 2026. Our 2030 vision is a SaaS vision.

Among all partnerships, vadiMAP is proud to be in connection with numerous partners across Canada, United States, Costa Rica, France, Benelux and Spain. See our Pitch Deck to see our human resources on slides 9, 10 and 11.
