ssf.sei_case_study_description:
The energy consumption of the vadiMAP Solution across its lifecycle primarily relates to cloud computing, as the platform’s AI, algorithms, and web applications are operated by both clients and our project office during the development of vadiMAP Prescriptions. In this sense, it is a software-based solution. Our cloud computing vendors are selected while taking into consideration their carbon footprint.

In regards with the measures prescribed by vadiMAP, see latest/attached LCA as it remains valid. vadiMAP has hundreds of cases and tens of thousands of simulations computing Scopes 1, 2 and 3 through its platform containing building cases, each with numerous energy efficiency and renewable measures.

For each Prescription (about 250 buildings and close to 100,000 simulate measures), the environmental impact is computed for scope 1 and scope 2. See pages 3-12 outlining a digital twin and 3 sets of measures with the full outcomes including GHG reduction.

See SEI file attached.
ssf.sei_production_phase:
As explained above, vadiMAP is a software-based solution which leaves the SEI relating to main materials to the measures prescribed and realized to our clients (see attached anonymized vadiMAP Prescription).

*****

See latest/attached LCA that remains valid for a measure prescribed to our Clients.

For each Prescription, a Bill of Material (BOM) is associated to each measure simulated. For instance, equipment, materials, and a BoS (Balance of System) is listed on a detailed list with associated labor costs. We do focus with vadiMAP Prescriptions on Scope 1 and Scope 2, and Scope 3 but only associated to the supply chain required to implement the measures we recommend (e.g. if Solar PV panels are prescribed, the CO2 associated to their production is included as an estimate). Our Scopes 1 and 2 are very accurate and detailed in each vadiMAP Prescription.
ssf.sei_transport: Idem: As explained above, vadiMAP is a software-based solution which leaves the SEI relating to main materials to the measures prescribed and realized to our clients (see attached anonymized vadiMAP Prescription).
ssf.sei_use_phase: Idem: As explained above, vadiMAP is a software-based solution which leaves the SEI relating to main materials to the measures prescribed and realized to our clients (see attached anonymized vadiMAP Prescription).
ssf.sei_disposal_phase:
See latest/attached LCA that remains valid.

For each Prescription, the measures simulated over a 25-year period include a disposal stage at the end of the useful life of the energy system on the building.
ssf.ei_energy_consumption_1: Per the GHG protocol, vadiMAP can reduce up to 100% of direct CO2 emissions (e.g. full replacement of a diesel generator) and tens/hundreds of tons of CO2 of indirect emissions (e.g. fossil-based generation from the main grid)
ssf.ei_energy_consumption_2: To displace 7.1 gigatons of carbon dioxide-equivalent,10% of all buildings (C&I) will be equipped with a system to generate electricity one-site by 2050
ssf.ei_energy_usage_1: In a vadiMAP Prescription for a greenhouse, the solar PV system recommended was ground-mounted with an installed power of 120 kW. Annually, it generates 30% of the energy needs, $ 29,700 of savings as well as a reduction of 19 tCO2e, for a payback period of 10 years.
ssf.ei_energy_usage_2: All vadiMAP Prescriptions contain a clear computation of GHG emissions with and without the measures best meeting the operational needs of each building.
ssf.ei_air_pollution_1: Renewable energy measures promoted by vadiMAP favor, always, the best option to avoid fossil fuels.
ssf.ei_other_1: There are no vadiMAP Prescriptions or sort of the buildings with the best energy potential without resiliency considerations. That matters so much for essential services to remain available during electricity blackouts.
ssf.economic:
One of the most important differentiator of vadiMAP relies in its AI technology used to ease economic decisions with clear information 'before' and 'after' each measure gets implemented. Please see on page 4 of the attached Prescription and following pages the metrics provided to the clients. That was among the 60,000+ hours of R&D including detailed datasets, algorithms and AI techniques.

****

Sales price (price range or ratio): The price points in section 5.3 have significant advantages over comparable approaches. Slide #4 of the deck also shows that a 10:1 ratio exists on price but also for the lead-time required to deliver prescription reports for traditional analysis as well as quality and consistency . For the nanogrid itself over time, vadiMAP is targeting to price its nanogrids 10% below the market price - thanks the reduction of soft costs (see "vadiMAP and Soft Costs"). Use cost over lifetime and Payback For each building, the payback time, the Return on Investment (ROI) and the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) is documented on the prescription report (see page 2 of the "Prescription Report Sample"). So the use cost varies (or LCOE) from one building to another, and of the many reasons building owners will purchase vadiMAP prescriptions to make informed decisions. In addition to quantifying savings made with with a nanogrid (called Objective 1), waste is considered and when logical, a storage battery is added to the optimal nanogrid (called Objective 2). In some cases, intangible benefits relating to a reduced carbon footprint (called Objective 3) will result in increased business traffic, employee retention and shareholder satisfaction. Therefore if the prescription report is favorable to swap centralized energy in favor of decentralized energy, the use cost over lifetime will be known including an estimate for maintenance and repair costs.
ssf.economic_intensity_detail:
All the measures computed with vadiMAP's AI includes CapEx and OpEx considerations. This is absolutely fundamental for building owners/operators to make sound decisions for their shareholders, customers and employees. All the competitors identified have not yet demonstrated such computed economics.

Capital intensity comes up in the vadiMAP questionnaire, for instance the respondent (representing the building owner or operator) might confirm the CapEx budget of the company is X or Y or none until otherwise budgeted. In such case and in line with the objective to reduce energy costs, OpEx-intensive measures will get a higher priority level. That would leave CapEx-intensive measures to next year when capital becomes available.
ssf.ef_directly_cheaper_1: Energy cost savings up to 30% than mainstream alternative AND payback within 2 year by avoiding waste and business interruption
ssf.ef_directly_cheaper_2: Intangible benefits for showing concrete actions: employee recruitment and retention, customer mindshare and shareholder satisfaction
ssf.ef_total_cost_1: Without a doubt, vadiMAP's AI levers make alternatives several times more expensive in terms of direct and indirect costs.

guidesectors.name: Utilities (Water, Energy, Waste)
guidesectors.definition: Solutions that allow for the comprehensive planning, coordination, and optimization of essential services related to water, energy, and waste. This sector involves the responsible and efficient provision, distribution, and management of these critical resources to support societal functions and ensure sustainable practices. It includes water management (sourcing, treatment, distribution), energy management (generation, storage, distribution) and waste management (collection, recycling, and treatment).

ssf.name: DRH4
ssf.one_sentence_description: High voltage transformer oil leak smart management system with early warning alarms
ssf.public_short_description:
The intelligent technology consists of a wide range of instrumentation, including early detection of oil leaks. All major components are made from green Canadian aluminum. The system operates as well in winter than summer thanks to efficient heating devices.
Rain water and oil and captured and driven to the instantaneous water-oil separator.  Water is filtered and directly release in the ground without any hydrocarbons.  Oil is recovered and strode in a temporary oil tank waiting to by refilter and reused.
ssf.environmental_benefit: By having a DRH4 installed on a high-voltage transformer, oil leaks no longer reach the ground thanks to its capture system. The earth and the underground water are therefore protected, as are flora and fauna. In addition, the captured oil is reusable, which reduces the purchase of hydrocarbon-based oil manufactured in factories.
ssf.economical_benefit: The DRH4 is five times less expensive than concrete alternatives. The system can be installed while the transformer is in production, avoiding these financial losses. Maintenance is simplified because the system is installed above ground instead of deep underground like concrete basins and separators. Oil from leaks is recovered, eliminating the need to purchase new oil.  Furthermore, since leaks no longer reach the ground, contamination is avoided, as are government fines. Transformer explosions due to oil loss are avoided, which boils down to the cost savings associated with repurchasing a transformer and huge production losses.
ssf.ss_description:
The DRH4 was install on a brand new substation transformer to add protection and keep the asset sustainable.  After less than a year, oil was detected.  The electrical manager were astonished to witness this case as any oil leaks were visible on the transformer.

Any testimony either pictures will be provided as we are under confidential contract with the federal government.  Although , one of the general information is this case.
ssf.ss_case_study_impact: The environment was saved from the oil spill and the client can use the data to do the preventive maintenance and save production loss.  Spill reports and declaration was also avoided as the oil was confine into a primary containment system without touching the ground, controlled and secured.
ssf.ss_grants_recognition: Best aluminum use and best innovation.  Many funding's were acquired for marketing.
ssf.technical_aspects:
We developed our technology during a 8 years R&D to create an instantaneous oil-water separator with these characteristics:

- 24/7 real time monitoring with distant alarms.
- Early stage oil leak detection
- High liquid flow (10,40 and 160 liters/minutes) depending on the model
- Instantaneous oil/water separation
- Automatic oil recovery
- No water storage since it is sent back to the ground with undetectable hydrocarbons (samples tested by the independent laboratory)
- Low elevation system suitable for flat ground (no heavy machinery required)
- Low weight system (Made of 100% green Canadian aluminum)
- Customizable and mobile
- Simple maintenance (2 x 1 hour a year) and reliable process

Capture plates are installed under cantilever parts of the transformer containing oil like coolers and the tap changer. If there is an oil leak from those components, they will be directed to the primary containment built on the transformer concrete base with low aluminum walls fixed around it.  The concrete base and the primary containment are sealed with a special resin concrete to avoid liquids to penetrate the porous concrete base.

As the containment is connected to the separator, rainwater, snowfall and oil leaks can enter to be processed.

The separator exit the water into a high efficiency filter to intercept any remaining oil concentration so to water can be release directly into the surrounding ground.

An oil recovery tank allows oil recycling since oil never touches the ground preventing natural waste like tree leave or dead insects from contaminating the oil.

A control panel mounted on a racking supervise a wide range of instrumentation to monitor all important transformer and DRH4 parameters.  Datalogging alarms provide historic to the management team to proceed to the right maintenance at the right moment.

All of the previous components from the separator to the control panel are mounted on a levelling platform.

Finally a sampler is installed at the filter exit for government authorities so they can eventually proceed to a laboratory water analysis.

Heating devices are installed for the extreme cold environment down to -40°C to prevent the water from freezing.  Several options are offered to satisfy all the needs of our customers.

The product is fabricated and assembly by a manufacturer partner.  All electrics and electronics devices are provided through US and Canadian suppliers.  CSA and UL standards are respected and IEEE recommended standards are exceeded.

Voltra supervise the client installation team or a third party installation service company to assure quality results.
ssf.human_assets:
The CEO, Marc Nadeau has a 18 year technician experience in waterpower stations and high voltage substations.  Also 10 year experience as a 1200 MW power dam operator.  He created the company Voltra in 2011.  He worked on many refurbishing, modernization and replacement projects in 4 power plants and 6 electrical substation.  Transformers are one of the high voltage equipment making part of the grid projects.  This is when he got his ideas about the system DRH4 developed by Voltra Technology.  Doing so, an important and unique worldwide system is participating to eliminate the high voltage transformer contamination.  He 

The original engineering Director, Christian Martel, has 3 years of experience as president of a service company, among one year as training officer for Mount Coffee Plant in Liberia, East Africa.  He was teacher, designer and project manager for 23 years then became the leader of a Technical training team for industrial clients. He was coordinating the activities of the designers and trainers and participating in the service management committee.  He was a production engineer and assistant general manager for 2 years in a granite company, working on bids, production planning, staff supervision, workshop drawing, production monitoring, quality control, and equipment commissioning.  He was a maintenance and project engineer for consulting firms for 2 years developing a maintenance program and commissioning production equipment.

The quality Director, Jocelyn Tremblay, has a 30 year experience in various sectors of the industry.  He spent 7 year in China to straighten out production processes for companies with significant stakes.

Communication & Marketing Directeur, Robert Doré, has a 40 years experience in events planning, politic relations and branding promotion.
ssf.external_threats:
We already sold units to sector's with the heaviest security protocols like the Canadian National Defense and pharmaceutical.  We also have a major utility in the Atlantic provinces and wind turbines in East Quebec.  Actually, major prospects in Ontario and Quebec are contacting us to integrate our solution into major projects taking place in eastern Canada.  We are keeping focus on representing Voltra at strategic events and doing several lunch and learn with engineering firms and main project contractors.

TAM-SAM-SOM information table attached below.
ssf.mainstream_alternative: The mainstream alternative is concrete installation including secondary containment and separators.  They are traditionally installed because their was anything else on the market.  These installations cost are incredibly high and complex to install in substation because they have to be underground.  The place it can be installed are also limited to substations with enough space and places like power dams can't use this alternative.
ssf.business_opportunity:
Until now, to solve the oil leak problem, there were few approaches :
- Avoid exposing the problem and managing to handle discreetly the oil leak events. Assuming the cost of fines and decontaminating when legally obligated.
- Installing big recuperation concrete basin and separator of high cost ranging from $ 1.06 M  to $ 3.5 M. (price comparison attach) 
- Installing basin with geomembranes
- Oil clogging plugs.

All these solutions do not allow to intervene at the first sign of leakage because their is no monitoring. Most of the time, a large oil spill is noted afterward. In every case, the soil surrounding the transformer has to be decontaminated and the system has to be restored. Production outage has to be anticipated and all of these is done at large expenses.

Our solution is affordable; more than 5 times less than concrete. Our system allows for fast action and has the potential to avoid problem deterioration, possible outages, and environmental disaster. Since no oil gets into contact with the soil, no decontamination is required and no fine is anticipated.
As little as one oil drop every 6 seconds cumulate almost 1,5 liters lost every day. Many transformers in operation has may of them which represent  hundred of oil liters.   This is an important issue since 70% of north America transformers met their useful life limit.  The DRH4 is the only smart system that allows a leaking transformer to stay in production and contribute to avoiding the catastrophic explosion.

Further more, there is no solution except the DRH4 that is operational in freezing conditions. 

Our customers may be electricity producer, distributors, and large consumers like big cities or industries (ex: smelters, paper mills, etc.). Our target is Northern America because only 20% of the 2 million transformers have a kind of oil leak protection
ssf.status:
We began Canadian, US marketing and Europe prospection in 2018 till March 2020.  Of course, we were force to stop our progress for a few years.  Since mid 2024, we are back on track making the industry aware of our technology.  We are hitting the perfect timing with new engineer generations and the search for an innovative solution at an affordable price.  We also started at the beginning of this year, partnership with First Nations who are implicated in large energy project.  They share our vision of environment protection so they show a lot of interest in our technology.

With our several manufacturer partners, we are ready to produce large scale production such as 300-500 units/year and the capacity of each manufacturer can be double with 8-10 months notice so that expansions can be made and additional equipment obtained.  Most of our manufacturer's can easily obtain the raw aluminum material in Canada where most of the aluminum production comes from in North America.  Furthermore, a large proportion of aluminum production comes from the province of Quebec where our manufacturer's are.
ssf.summary_market_of_application: The DRH4 is the only smart monitoring system for transformer oil leaks with early stage detection and distant alarms.
ssf.summary_market_of_application_2: The DRH4 is the first system all category able to separate water and oil instantaneously and to release water with undetectable hydrocarbons
ssf.summary_market_of_application_3: The DRH4 is the only system able to capture oil and manage water-oil separation at -40°C.
ssf.sei_case_study_description: One of our client, Haleon (Glaxo-Smith-Kline) had an issue with a building transformer on the roof of one of their manufacture since 2016.  They searched worldwide in partnership with their insurance company to find a solution to avoid contaminating the storm sewer system through the roof drain nearby.  They needed a system able to capture oil leak, monitor and adress the leakage and release water to the drain without any trace of hydrocarbons.  One the main problem was that the solution had to be light enough for the roof structure, so concrete solution was not possible at all.  This issue last 6 years until a technician in Montreal, Quebec discovered our technology.  We solve it in two days by adapting the system in the available space to meet all GSK requirements (see picture attach) .  The insurance company AXA and GSK head office approved Voltra and the DRH4 as the official supplier and technology for this kind of situation.
ssf.sei_production_phase:
For the same project:

A typical concrete installation (secondary containment & separator) for a single transformer will have an average concrete  weight is 546 839 kg (603 ton) which equals 603 ton of CO2.  This do not include reinforcing steel used in these concrete structures.

The raw material of our system is aluminum.  For the DRH4-V2 system which is the middle model with cooler capturing plates in option (often offered with the main system) is 388 kg (0.43 ton) which equals 0.86 ton of CO2.  This a tiny fraction of the concrete weight and also as the energy to produce de solution.  Concrete is also done in a plant, transported by heavy fuel trucks and the space to construct the concrete basin is also done by heavy digging fuel machinery.

The electricity consume for one concrete installation is 150 750 KWh and the DRH4 is 5805 KWh.

So DRH4 consume 26 times less electricity and 1402 times less CO2 emissions than a concrete solution.

Considering the raw materiel treated above, the DRH4 lifetime is 80 years and the concrete can stand up to same time but will be strongly affected by ground movement and humidity since the concrete solution is underground.
ssf.sei_transport: The main material is aluminum.  A large part of it is produce in Saguenay, a region 2 hour North of Quebec City, where Voltra's have its head office.  However, the material like plates and profiled products used to manufacture any type of aluminum components, comes from other Canadian or American region and transported by truck.
ssf.sei_use_phase:
DRH4
During winter, the average consumption is 4934 kwh.

Concrete
There is no electric consumption because there is no controller neither than heating devices.  This is exactly why it doesn't work in winter.

For the same transformer, the amount of water that is contaminated per year:
DRH4: 63.3 m³ of water treated with no hydrocarbons release 

Concrete: 234.4 m³ of water treated with 2-100 ppm (maybe more) of hydrocarbons release
ssf.sei_disposal_phase:
DRH4

The aluminum and other metallic components like stainless valves are fully recyclable.  All the electronics can be send in recycling center to be dissembled.  The fiberglass from the control panel can be recycled where there are facilities to do so.

Concrete
No second life is known unless to use it for landfill.
ssf.ei_energy_usage_1: By capturing all hydrocarbons, we contribute to eliminate 100% ground contamination in electric substations
ssf.ei_biodiversity_1: By releasing 100% clean rainwater into nature, we contribute to keep underground's water  clean and save for all living beings.
ssf.ei_air_pollution_1: By replacing concrete solutions, we can replace one of the most air polluting industries, namely cement production plants
ssf.economic:
The economic impact is to be considered on three points of view.

For new transformer installation, insurance company or environment authorities require to include a protection on the drawings before giving their approval to start the project.  As mentioned before, concrete is often suggested.  You can consult the 2024 cost comparison between concrete and the DRH4 in the table attach.

Money saved is between $ 840 000 CAD and $ 2 780 000.

For an existing transformer installation, adding concrete protection is usually very complex because of the excavating and turning off the transformer.  Additional cost to the prices in the comparison table has to be expected to decontaminate civil material since there is a need to remove the existing soil most likely contaminated.
The DRH4 doesn't require excavating neither transformer outage and there is no need for soil decontamination since no soil is removed or replaced. Savings are usually higher than the amount mentioned previously.

The maintenance:
-The DRH4 only need a visual inspection twice a year instead of a heavy maintenance program with special equipment's to verify concrete integrity.
-The DRH4 don't have enclosed space so no need to apply this protocol during inspection.
-No need to send personnel to distant sites to verify oil leak since the DRH4 does 24/7 monitoring (only system with monitoring worldwide)

Considering the decision of not putting protection, the cost can easily reach $10 millions for a major spill:
-Asset loss
-Production loss
-Emergency intervention
-Governmental fine
-Soil rehabilitation 
-Water decontamination
ssf.economic_intensity_detail: To do a transformer protection project, investment is made on a few months during the installation.  This is the case of any type of protection.  The decision that shall be made is to pay more or less for the initial investment.  DRH4 operating costs are variable depending of the transformer condition.  Oil leak detection needs a special cartridge which have to be replace when detection is made.  Filter and other components are long lasting that needs very less maintenance.  Expected lifetime is between 5 and 15 years.  The system itself is expected to last 50-60 years.  So even if the DRH4 needs an initial investment, the operational cost are very low comparing to what is usually known from the industry.
ssf.ef_directly_cheaper_1: The DRH4 is 5 times cheaper than concrete alternative and give 10 times more benefits
ssf.ef_directly_cheaper_2: If the system is used on an active leaking system (around 1 oil drop every 6 seconds) the time to get a return on the investment is evaluated in less than 3 weeks considering cost avoided.

solutions_of_the_month.one_sentence_description: Eco Wave Power has developed a technology for the generation of clean electricity from ocean and sea waves.
solutions_of_the_month.supporting:
Eco Wave Power is a leading onshore wave energy company revolutionizing clean energy with its patented, smart, and cost-efficient technology that converts ocean and sea waves into sustainable electricity.

Dedicated to combating climate change, Eco Wave Power operates the first grid-connected wave energy system in Israel, co-funded by EDF Renewables IL and the Israeli Energy Ministry, which recognized the technology as a “Pioneering Technology.”

Expanding globally, Eco Wave Power is preparing to install projects at the Port of Los Angeles, Taiwan, and Portugal, adding to its impressive project pipeline totalling 404.7 MW. The company has received support from prestigious institutions such as the European Union Regional Development Fund, Innovate UK, and the Horizon 2020 program, and was honoured with the United Nations’ Global Climate Action Award.

Eco Wave Power’s American Depositary Shares (WAVE) are traded on the Nasdaq Capital Market.
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_1: Wave Energy Potential: Utilizing all suitable locations worldwide, wave energy has the potential to produce twice the current global energy output, making it a massive untapped source of clean energy
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_2: Energy Production: A 1 MW wave energy power station can power approximately 1,000 households, providing reliable, renewable electricity to local communities
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_3: Coastal Population: Around 60% of the global population lives within 200 km of the coastline, which makes wave energy an ideal solution
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_4: Based on Eco Wave Power’s calculations, a 1MW power station with a 40% capacity factor can prevent approximately 2,477 metric tons of CO₂ emissions per year (according to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s greenhouse gas equivalencies calculator)
solutions_of_the_month.public_key_feature_5: A key advantage of Eco Wave Power is our ability to connect to existing structures, like breakwaters, reducing the need for new offshore infrastructure
solutions_of_the_month.profitability_1: Eco Wave Power’s 100kW station costs $450,000 USD, significantly less than the $150 million USD cost of the Pelamis system for a similar capacity
solutions_of_the_month.profitability_2: Eco Wave Power’s solution requires minimal maintenance costs compared to traditional offshore wave energy systems

ssf.name: Eco Wave Power - Wave Energy
ssf.one_sentence_description: Eco Wave Power has developed a technology for the generation of clean electricity from ocean and sea waves.
ssf.public_short_description:
Eco Wave Power is a leading onshore wave energy company revolutionizing clean energy with its patented, smart, and cost-efficient technology that converts ocean and sea waves into sustainable electricity.

Dedicated to combating climate change, Eco Wave Power operates the first grid-connected wave energy system in Israel, co-funded by EDF Renewables IL and the Israeli Energy Ministry, which recognized the technology as a “Pioneering Technology.”

Expanding globally, Eco Wave Power is preparing to install projects at the Port of Los Angeles, Taiwan, and Portugal, adding to its impressive project pipeline totaling 404.7 MW. The company has received support from prestigious institutions such as the European Union Regional Development Fund, Innovate UK, and the Horizon 2020 program, and was honored with the United Nations’ Global Climate Action Award.

Eco Wave Power’s American Depositary Shares (WAVE) are traded on the Nasdaq Capital Market.
ssf.environmental_benefit: A key environmental benefit of Eco Wave Power’s solution is that our technology does not connect to the ocean floor, distinguishing it from many other wave energy systems. This unique design minimizes the impact on marine ecosystems and preserves the natural integrity of the seafloor and local biodiversity. By using floating platforms that are anchored to existing coastal infrastructure, such as piers or breakwaters, we avoid disrupting marine life or habitats. This non-intrusive approach ensures that the ocean floor remains undisturbed, allowing marine ecosystems to thrive while generating clean, renewable energy. The result is a sustainable, eco-friendly solution that provides reliable energy while protecting the marine environment from physical damage or habitat disruption, contributing to the global effort to combat climate change and reduce dependency on fossil fuels.
ssf.economical_benefit: Eco Wave Power’s solution offers considerable economic benefits for clients by providing a cost-effective, renewable energy source that helps lower energy costs in coastal and island regions. In many such areas, energy is traditionally expensive due to reliance on imported fossil fuels or remote generation. Our wave energy technology offers a sustainable and stable alternative, with the potential for significant long-term cost savings. The modular design of our system makes it adaptable to various scales and settings, reducing installation and operational costs. Moreover, by reducing dependence on imported energy, Eco Wave Power can help create energy independence for coastal regions. The solution also offers economic opportunities through the creation of jobs in installation, maintenance, and local manufacturing, driving economic growth and energy security for communities worldwide.
ssf.ss_description: Eco Wave Power installed and is currently operating a 100-kW installed capacity station at the Jaffa Port in Israel through a Joint Venture Agreement with EDF Renewables IL. EWP also received co-funding from the Israeli Ministry of Energy, which recognized the technology as a “pioneering technology.” As of August 15th, 2023, the station officially connected to Israel’s national electrical grid – making it the first wave energy project to deliver electricity to the country’s power supply. The EWP EDF One project is currently subject to constant R&D development and continuous calibration. The performative improvements gained are to be deployed in our first commercial-scale project in Portugal. The results from the project are encouraging, as we can see a month-by-month improvement both in terms of the energy generation results and in terms of a significant decrease in system downtime.
ssf.ss_case_study_impact:
The project is significantly contributing to reducing the carbon footprint by generating clean renewable energy from wave power and directly transmitting to local grid, which helps reduce reliance on fossil fuels, leading to a reduction in CO2 emissions. 

The project has had a positive impact on the economy by creating local jobs and supporting local industries. Throughout the development and implementation phases, the project generated employment opportunities for a variety of skilled workers.
ssf.ss_grants_recognition: In addition to IPO proceeds, EWP has secured multiple grants that support research, development, and commercialization efforts such as the Iliad Grant (part of the European Green Deal), Innovate UK, The Israeli Chief Scientist of Energy program, and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF). These funding sources, combined with strategic partnerships with stakeholders like EDF, Shell MRE, and Bharat Petroleum are essential in enabling EWP to scale its technology and pursue new opportunities.
ssf.technical_aspects:
The Eco Wave Power system harnesses the kinetic energy of ocean and sea waves to generate clean electricity. The technology operates by attaching floaters to existing manmade marine structures such as breakwaters, jetties, and piers. The floaters move up and down with the motion of the waves, initiating a mechanical energy conversion process.

More precisely, the rising and falling motion of the floaters compresses and decompresses hydraulic pistons, which pump biodegradable hydraulic fluid into land-based accumulators. Within these accumulators, pressure builds up, which is used to rotate a hydraulic motor. This motor then powers a generator that produces electricity. The produced electricity is transferred to the grid via an inverter. After use, the hydraulic fluid returns to a fluid tank and is reused in a closed-loop system, ensuring no environmental discharge.

The system begins generating electricity from wave heights as low as 0.5 meters, enabling it to operate effectively even in relatively calm seas. A smart automation and control system continuously monitors the performance and environmental conditions. In the event of extreme wave activity or storms, the floaters automatically lift out of the water and lock in an upward position to prevent damage. Once the storm passes, the system autonomously resumes normal operation.

Technical Highlights:
•	Grid Connection: Systems are fully grid-integrated and comply with standard grid codes.
•	Modular Design: Floaters can be added or removed easily, allowing for scalable deployment.
•	Onshore Hydraulic Conversion: All sensitive components (pistons, motors, generators) are located on land, simplifying maintenance and significantly reducing costs compared to offshore systems.

Intellectual Property & Patents:
Eco Wave Power holds a robust portfolio of 18 patents, registered in key global markets including the United States, Europe, and Israel. These patents cover various aspects of the technology, including:
•	Floater structure and installation methods
•	Energy conversion process and hydraulic mechanisms
•	Smart control system and storm protection mechanism
•	Environmental integration with existing coastal infrastructure

System Lifespan & Maintenance:
The expected lifespan of an Eco Wave Power installation is 25 years, in line with other renewable energy technologies like solar and wind. Due to the land-based design, which avoids corrosion and biofouling typically seen in underwater components, the system enjoys lower operational and maintenance costs and higher system availability. Routine maintenance can be conducted without the need for divers or offshore vessels, further reducing lifecycle costs.

Under her leadership, EWP built the first grid-connected wave energy array and developed a project pipeline of over 404.7 MW. She’s been recognized by Wired, Fast Company, and received the UN Global Climate Action Award. Inna holds a BA in Political Science from Haifa University and holds 18 patents across Israel, the U.S., and Europe. She has played a key role in shaping marine energy policies, including the Marine Energy Technologies Acceleration Act, a $1 billion investment to advance marine energy.

ssf.external_threats:
The global wave energy market is projected to grow significantly, with the renewable energy market reaching $1.5 trillion by 2027. The ocean energy potential is estimated at 30,000 TWh annually, and the Total Addressable Market (TAM) for wave energy is projected to be around $60 billion by 2030, which includes both wave power generation systems and related infrastructure. Our Serviceable Addressable Market (SAM) targets coastal regions such as the U.K., U.S., Japan, and parts of Europe, where offshore and nearshore energy solutions are in high demand. Regions with existing port infrastructure and a focus on renewable energy transition provide clear opportunities, and we estimate the SAM to be $5-10 billion by 2030. Our Share of Market (SOM) will be driven by initial pilot projects, such as the Jaffa Port installation, which are critical for proving wave energy’s viability due to current legislative and policy limitations. These projects serve as the foundation for scaling and commercializing wave energy solutions.

Go-to-Market Strategy:
Value Proposition: EWP’s technology offers clean, cost-effective energy with minimal environmental impact, utilizing existing infrastructure like breakwaters to provide a scalable, low-maintenance wave energy solution.

Target Markets: Coastal regions with port infrastructure, focusing on countries with strong renewable energy targets and access to the global energy grid.

Partnerships: We plan to collaborate with local governments, port authorities, energy providers, and engineering firms to expand market access and build a local ecosystem.

Competitive Advantage: Our use of existing infrastructure reduces costs and environmental impact, while our modular design allows for scalable, efficient deployment across coastal regions.

Sales & Marketing: We will leverage studies like Jaffa Port to demonstrate our technology’s effectiveness and environmental benefits, focusing on building relationships and engaging in policy advocacy.
ssf.mainstream_alternative: The mainstream alternative Eco Wave Power replaces is fossil fuel-based electricity generation—particularly diesel, coal, and natural gas—which still powers a majority of coastal and island regions. Diesel generators, are costly, polluting, and subject to volatile fuel prices. EWP provides a clean, stable alternative using wave energy from existing coastal infrastructure, offering a more sustainable and economically viable solution for regions dependent on imported fossil fuels.
ssf.business_opportunity:
Current alternatives include offshore wave energy technologies such as Oscilla Power, Carnegie Clean Energy, and the former Pelamis system. These systems typically require deep-water deployment, complex underwater mooring, cabling, and extensive maintenance in harsh marine environments—making them capital intensive, environmentally risky, and difficult to scale. Many offshore wave ventures have struggled to remain viable due to high costs, low survivability, and limited access for repairs.

Eco Wave Power sets itself apart as the only wave energy technology that is entirely onshore, installed on existing structures like breakwaters and piers. This results in drastically lower installation and operational costs, simplified maintenance (with all components accessible from land), and no impact on the ocean floor or marine ecosystems.

Compared to other renewables, EWP complements solar and wind by providing predictable energy generation in coastal areas, particularly when solar is low (e.g., at night or during storms). Our modular design allows for scalable implementation, and our grid-connected project in Jaffa Port proves the commercial and environmental viability of our approach—offering a more pragmatic, deployable path forward for wave energy.
ssf.status:
Eco Wave Power’s scaling strategy focuses on leveraging successful pilot projects, strategic partnerships, and adaptable business models to expand wave energy adoption globally. Our first proof of concept was the Gibraltar project, which demonstrated our technology’s potential. The Jaffa Port project followed, becoming the first wave energy installation to connect to Israel’s national grid, marking a key milestone in wave energy adoption. These successes will guide our global expansion into regions with strong renewable energy goals and available coastal infrastructure.

Eco Wave Power operates with three business models—Joint Ventures (JV), Build-Own-Operate (BOO), and Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT)—to tailor our approach to local market needs and financing. Our JV with EDF Renewables at Jaffa Port has helped scale our technology in Israel, while our partnerships with Shell and AltaSea at the Port of Los Angeles aim to bring wave energy to the U.S. In India, we’ve partnered with Bharat Petroleum to tap into the growing renewable energy market, and our collaboration with I-Ke International Ocean Energy in Taiwan helps navigate Asian infrastructure needs.

To scale further, we will continue licensing agreements with local partners, collaborating with engineering firms, and offering long-term operation and maintenance contracts, ensuring efficient deployment and reliable service. We will also strengthen ties with port authorities, governments, and utilities in coastal regions, working with development banks and national energy programs to integrate wave energy into long-term strategies.

Through these partnerships and business models, Eco Wave Power is well-positioned to scale its solution globally, accelerating the shift to renewable energy in coastal regions.
ssf.summary_market_of_application: Wave Energy Potential: According to the US Energy Information Administration, wave energy can provide around 66% of all US energy needs.  Source: https://www.eia.gov/energyexplained/hydropower/wave-power.php
ssf.summary_market_of_application_2: The International Panel on Climate Change, the UNs climate panel, estimates the worldwide potential for wave energy is over 29,500 TWh/year. Source: (Chapter 6.4.2.9)- https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg3/chapter/chapter-6/
ssf.summary_market_of_application_3: Coastal Population: Over 50% of the global population lives within 200 km of the coastline, which makes wave energy an ideal solution. Since our technology is deployed on existing coastal infrastructure, we can directly provide clean energy to these coastal populations. https://www.oceansatlas.org/s
ssf.sei_case_study_description:
The Jaffa Port 100KW Wave Energy Project, launched in 2023, harnesses ocean waves to generate sustainable electricity. Developed by Eco Wave Power (EWP) in partnership with EDF Renewables IL and co-funded by the Israeli Ministry of Energy, the project marks a significant step in wave energy commercialization. Under a 20% capacity factor, a 100 kW station can produce approximately 175,200 kWh of electricity annually.

Located at the historic Jaffa Port in Tel Aviv-Yafo, Israel, this project benefits from strategic coastal positioning, aligning with the city’s clean energy goals. By utilizing existing breakwater infrastructure, the project reduces the need for costly offshore construction. EWP, a global leader in onshore wave energy, leads the project, with EDF Renewables IL providing expertise and the Ministry of Energy supporting with financial backing.

The Jaffa Port project aims to demonstrate the scalability and cost-effectiveness of wave energy, addressing global energy challenges caused by fossil fuel dependency. Unlike solar and wind energy, wave energy is reliable and predictable. The technology uses floaters attached to marine structures, where wave movement drives hydraulic pistons, generating pressure that’s converted into electricity through a hydraulic motor and generator. The energy is then transmitted to the grid.

Key advantages include cost efficiency, storm protection—where floaters automatically rise during extreme weather—and minimal environmental impact, as no seabed drilling is required. The Jaffa Port project has proven the commercial viability of wave energy and serves as a model for larger-scale deployments. It provides valuable insights for future projects in Europe, North America, and Asia, advancing global renewable energy transitions.
ssf.sei_production_phase:
Eco Wave Power’s onshore wave energy technology is designed to be materially efficient and environmentally low-impact by leveraging existing coastal infrastructure and centralizing all sensitive components on land. The primary materials used in the production of the system include steel for the floaters, structural arms, mounting brackets, and supporting frameworks; protective marine-grade coatings and paints for corrosion resistance; and copper used in the electrical wiring and generator windings. Additional components include biodegradable hydraulic fluid in a closed-loop circuit, rubber and polymer elements for hydraulic seals and tubing, and glass and electronic components for the control system, sensors, automation, and monitoring units. In some cases, aluminum may be used for enclosures and lightweight housing elements. Each floater requires approximately 3,000 kg of steel. In addition to steel, the station also includes components such as hydraulic cylinders, pipes, pumps, accumulators, motors, and generators.

In contrast, a conventional offshore wave energy system, such as floating point absorbers or seabed-anchored oscillating devices, involves significantly more material-intensive construction. These systems require large quantities of steel for the buoy structures, anchoring frames, and submerged platforms, as well as concrete for gravity-based foundations or mooring blocks installed on the seabed. Copper is used in subsea power transmission and generators, while fiberglass or carbon fiber composites are often employed to reduce weight in buoyant elements. Rubber, polymers, and synthetic mooring lines (e.g., nylon or HMPE) are used for flexible joints, subsea cabling, and anchoring. These offshore systems also depend heavily on marine-grade resins and sealants to ensure long-term durability in harsh ocean environments, and their electronics must be specially designed for full marine submersion and remote operation.
ssf.sei_transport:
Eco Wave Power's wave energy system prioritizes sustainability and efficiency throughout its lifecycle. The floaters, key structural components, are produced locally near the project site. This reduces transportation emissions, supports local economies, and ensures site-specific customization.

The conversion unit, responsible for transforming wave energy into electricity, is manufactured in Israel. This includes the hydraulic motor, generator, control cabinet, automation systems, and wiring. Once assembled, the system is pre-installed and tested within a standardized shipping container, ready for rapid deployment. It is then shipped directly to the project site, minimizing on-site assembly.

Eco Wave Power’s strategic partnerships with industry leaders such as Siemens and Bosch enhance system reliability. Siemens supplies advanced control and automation systems, ensuring smooth operation, while Bosch contributes high-quality electrical components. These collaborations guarantee the performance and durability of the technology.

Throughout the system's operation, the floaters remain stationary, and the conversion unit, located on land, requires minimal transportation for maintenance. Parts replacement and upgrades are efficiently carried out using onshore tools and nearby facilities, further reducing environmental impact.

By sourcing floaters locally and shipping containerized systems from Israel, combined with trusted partnerships, Eco Wave Power ensures an efficient, environmentally responsible approach to production, transportation, and operation.
ssf.sei_use_phase:
Eco Wave Power’s solution has minimal resource consumption during its use phase. It generates renewable energy from ocean waves and does not consume significant amounts of water, as it operates without using freshwater or seawater for any processes. Occasional maintenance or part replacements are required, but these are minimal compared to traditional power plants. Emissions are negligible, with only minimal emissions from maintenance activities and transportation.

In contrast, fossil fuel-based power plants consume large amounts of energy from coal, oil, or natural gas, with a constant need for fuel supply during operation. They also require substantial water for cooling, which can impact local water resources and ecosystems. These plants consume significant raw materials, such as fuel and chemicals, and have a higher level of infrastructure consumption. Additionally, fossil fuel plants generate high levels of CO2 and other pollutants, contributing to climate change and air pollution.

In summary, Eco Wave Power’s solution offers a far lower resource consumption profile, relying primarily on wave energy, while fossil fuel plants have much higher energy, water, and material consumption and produce significant emissions.
ssf.sei_disposal_phase:
At the end of its life cycle, Eco Wave Power’s system is designed to minimize environmental impact through responsible disposal and recycling. Materials like steel, aluminum, and copper are highly recyclable. Steel and aluminum components, such as floaters and structural arms, can be melted down and reused, reducing the need for raw material extraction. Copper, used in wiring and generators, can also be recycled for new electrical systems.

Marine-grade coatings and paints, which protect against corrosion, can be safely removed and disposed of according to environmental regulations. Components made from rubber and polymers, like seals and tubing, are minimized, and when no longer usable, are disposed of through environmentally friendly waste management processes.

Hydraulic fluid used in the system is biodegradable, posing minimal environmental risk. Any waste would be handled according to disposal protocols to ensure safety. Electronic components, including sensors and control systems, are sent to e-waste recycling programs, reducing landfill impact.

In summary, Eco Wave Power’s system is designed with end-of-life disposal in mind, prioritizing recycling, reuse, and safe disposal to minimize environmental impact. This approach is more sustainable compared to conventional offshore wave energy systems, which can involve the challenging disposal of materials like fiberglass, carbon fiber, and synthetic mooring lines.
ssf.ei_energy_consumption_1: Based on Eco Wave Power’s calculations, a 1MW power station with a 40% capacity factor can prevent approximately 2,477 metric tons of CO₂ emissions per year (according to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s greenhouse gas equivalencies calculator).
ssf.ei_air_pollution_1: Eco Wave Power reduces air pollution by generating clean electricity from ocean waves, replacing fossil fuel-based energy, and improves public health by lowering greenhouse gas emissions and particulate matter that contribute to respiratory illnesses and
ssf.ei_other_1: A key advantage of Eco Wave Power is our ability to connect to existing structures, like breakwaters, reducing the need for new infrastructure. This minimizes environmental impact, cuts installation time and costs, and allows for seamless integration.
ssf.economic:
Economic Incentives of Eco Wave Power’s Solution:

1. Competitive Pricing- Once commercialized, wave energy will be comparable in price to traditional energy generation methods, offering a sustainable and cost-competitive alternative to fossil fuels and other renewables.

2. Job Creation and Economic Growth- Wave energy will create a new industry, providing local employment opportunities and contributing to economic growth, particularly in coastal communities. 

3. Coastal Erosion Mitigation- The floaters used in our system are installed on breakwaters, providing additional protection against coastal erosion. This reduces the need for costly breakwater repairs, saving funds for port authorities and governments responsible for maintaining these structures.

4. Lower Capital and Maintenance Costs- In a commercial sized project, defined as 20 MW or greater, the cost of our system is $1.5 million USD per MW, significantly lower than offshore systems, which typically exceed $10 million USD per MW. 

5. Faster Return on Investment (ROI)- Our projects have an expected ROI within 3-5 years, significantly faster than most competitors, who are still in their R&D phase and have yet to generate any return.

6. Feed-In Tariff (FIT) Incentives- Our solution benefits from favorable Feed-In Tariffs (FIT), with many countries offering higher FIT rates for wave energy compared to fossil-fuel-based electricity, providing an additional financial incentive.

7. Environmental and Health Savings- Our systems produce clean, renewable electricity with zero emissions, significantly reducing national pollution levels and the associated healthcare costs. This makes wave energy a key player in reducing fossil fuel dependence and mitigating the environmental and health impacts of traditional energy sources.


Comparison with Fossil-Fuel-Based Electricity:
In comparison to fossil-fuel-based electricity, wave energy offers the following economic advantages:

1. Price Stability- Wave energy provides a predictable pricing model compared to the volatility of fossil fuel prices, making it a more stable long-term energy solution.

2. Reduced External Costs- Fossil fuels incur significant external costs related to pollution, health issues, and environmental damage. Wave energy, on the other hand, produces zero emissions and reduces these costs.

3. Job Creation- While fossil fuels face job losses due to automation and transitioning energy systems, wave energy will create new, sustainable jobs in the renewable energy sector.

Due to a non-disclosure agreement (NDA) with EDF regarding the Jaffa Port project, we are unable to disclose specific cost figures. However, based on our commercial-scale projections and current operational data, electricity generated by Eco Wave Power’s system can cost as low as $0.05 USD/kWh. This positions our technology as cost-competitive with solar and wind in regions with strong wave activity, while offering the added benefit of consistent, predictable output during both day and night. In the long run, the economic and environmental benefits of wave energy make it a competitive and sustainable alternative to fossil-fuel-based electricity.
ssf.economic_intensity_detail:
The initial capital intensity of Eco Wave Power’s solution is relatively high compared to the operating costs throughout its lifetime, but it is more cost-effective than many alternative renewable energy technologies.

However, once installed, the operating costs are relatively low. Maintenance is minimal compared to traditional offshore systems, as Eco Wave Power connects to existing infrastructure, such as breakwaters, reducing the need for costly subsea installations or regular deep-water maintenance. Additionally, the system operates with low energy consumption for its own function, as it is grid-connected, reducing long-term operational expenses.

Thus, while the initial capital investment can be a significant part of the overall cost, the low operational and maintenance costs throughout the system’s life make it a highly cost-effective solution over time, providing strong long-term value for adopters.
ssf.ef_directly_cheaper_1: Eco Wave Power’s 100kW station costs $450,000 USD, significantly less than the $150 million USD cost of the Pelamis system for a similar capacity. This cost advantage, combined with our ability to integrate into existing infrastructure, makes EWP a more a
ssf.ef_directly_cheaper_2: EWP’s solution requires minimal maintenance costs compared to traditional offshore wave energy systems by placing all machinery on land, enabling easy access and reducing long-term operational expenses.

implementationstories.title: Eco Wave Power Adopted by The Port of Los Angeles
implementationstories.description_client: The Port of Los Angeles Wave Energy Station is Eco Wave Power’s first U.S.-based project and marks the first onshore wave energy installation in the United States. Developed in collaboration with AltaSea and Shell MRE, the project showcases Eco Wave Power’s innovative technology, which uses floaters installed on existing marine structures to harvest green electricity from ocean and sea waves. As the floaters rise and fall with wave motion, they release a biodegradable fluid, which presses hydraulic pistons that drive a land-based generator to produce clean electricity. Set to become officially operational in September 2025, the station demonstrates how wave energy can be integrated into existing port infrastructure to diversify renewable energy sources, reduce carbon emissions, and support coastal resilience. This project aims to address the need for sustainable, locally generated power in urban coastal environments, while proving the viability of wave energy in the U.S. market.
implementationstories.description_result: Eco Wave Power’s Los Angeles project focuses on R&D and environmental assessment in collaboration with the Port of LA, AltaSea, Shell MRE, and PNNL, serving as a regulatory pathway for wave energy in the U.S. It supports the creation of a new local industry, driving job creation, coastal innovation, and renewable infrastructure development. The project contributes to emissions reductions, energy diversification, and long-term economic and environmental resilience.

implementationstories.title: Tel Aviv-Jaffa turns breakwaters into clean energy infrastructure
implementationstories.quote:
Wave energy generation is a big challenge; the energy of the waves is beyond what
the usual human construction can sustain. Therefore, it is very difficult to build something that will produce energy offshore (middle of the ocean), this is why we like the idea
of Eco Wave Power.
implementationstories.description_client: Located in Tel Aviv-Yafo, the site aligns with the city’s renewable energy goals and was selected for its strategic coastal position. In 2023, Eco Wave Power launched the Jaffa Port 100 kW Wave Energy Project in Tel Aviv-Yafo, in partnership with EDF Renewables IL and co-funded by the Israeli Ministry of Energy. Designed as a scalable, cost-effective alternative to fossil fuels, the project addresses energy security and complements solar and wind power. The system was installed directly on existing breakwaters, enabling a low-footprint solution with minimal marine impact. The grid connection was facilitated by the Israel Electric Company, while permitting and site access were supported by the Municipality of Tel Aviv-Jaffa, Atarim Group, and Jaffa Port Authority. This demonstration site now serves as a model for scalable, locally integrated wave energy deployment in other coastal cities worldwide.

A 100 kW station with 40% capacity can prevent up to 247.7 metric tonnes of CO₂ emissions annually (per US EPA equivalency tools). Created 5 full-time engineering positions, 1 pilot station technician, and 20+ indirect jobs in floaters production, environmental studies, and local civil works.
