ssf.name: Smr300
ssf.one_sentence_description: A smart, connected blue roof platform that manages rainwater and mitigates floods in real-time.
ssf.public_short_description: SmartFlow is an intelligent rooftop system that helps cities prevent floods by controlling rainwater in real time. It can be installed on new or existing buildings and uses smart sensors and algorithms to make data-driven decisions that protect urban areas from water damage.
ssf.environmental_benefit: SmartFlow reduces urban flood impact by over 30% without the need for major infrastructure changes. It enables real-time, network-based control of rainwater flow, contributing to climate adaptation and resilient urban planning.
ssf.economical_benefit: SmartFlow provides a cost-effective solution for construction companies, municipalities, property management firms, and insurers. It enables compliance with local rainwater regulations at minimal cost and installation time, offering a scalable alternative to traditional infrastructure-heavy approaches.
ssf.ss_title: Rainwater compliance solved in a fast, affordable and non-invasive way
ssf.ss_description: A new residential building in central Tel Aviv was constructed on the site of a demolished old house. The local municipality required compliance with new rainwater retention regulations. Due to structural and space constraints, traditional solutions such as underground tanks were not feasible. SmartFlow was the only affordable and technically applicable system that could be installed quickly at the end of the construction phase – without redesign or excavation.
ssf.ss_case_study_impact: Without SmartFlow, the project faced regulatory rejection due to lack of feasible drainage. The client completed the installation in half a day and resolved the issue with a $30K investment – enabling project approval and avoiding major redesign costs.
ssf.ss_grants_recognition: The solution was entirely bootstrapped from the beginning, with no external grants or funding to date. We are now approaching a major milestone through commercial adoption.
ssf.technical_aspects:
SmartFlow is a smart system that controls rainwater on rooftops using sensors and valves. It detects rainfall and water levels, and opens or closes valves to prevent flooding or overflow. The system is automatic, works in real time, and can be monitored and controlled remotely.
SmartFlow is a modular stormwater control platform that leverages IoT, edge computing, and cloud-based AI to dynamically manage urban runoff at the source. The system consists of an embedded hardware controller installed at rooftop drainage points or retention tanks, connected to a suite of environmental sensors (e.g., ultrasonic level sensors, flow meters, rain gauges). Data is sampled in real time and pre-processed locally using an on-device microcontroller (ESP32 or similar), which handles immediate decision-making in case of network latency. Sensor data is then transmitted via MQTT protocol to a cloud server, where SmartFlow’s AI engine aggregates multi-site inputs, integrates external weather APIs, and runs predictive models based on LSTM neural networks to forecast runoff scenarios. Using reinforcement learning and decision-tree logic, the system determines optimal valve positions and activates custom-built electromechanical actuators to modulate flow rates. This real-time feedback loop enables localized flood prevention, optimized retention for green infrastructure, and improved hydrological resilience across dense urban zones. The architecture supports remote firmware updates, API integrations with BMS/SCADA systems, and full compliance with municipal standards for smart infrastructure.
Please see the attached technical document for architecture diagrams, system components, and control logic.
ssf.human_assets: Our solution is driven by a highly experienced and multidisciplinary founding team. Moshe, our co-founder and first investor, has over 25 years of expertise in stormwater management, leading large-scale drainage projects through Peleg Rainwater Solutions and Tip Top, a piping contractor for major infrastructure developments. The core development team includes Snir and Moti, both former IDF tank officers (Majors, Res.) with extensive experience in the Israeli Ministry of Defense’s tank R&D division (IMoD). Snir served as Head of AI Systems, while Moti led Software & Cybersecurity for armored platforms. Both hold MSc degrees in engineering and have a proven track record of building a successful cleantech company in the urban sanitation sector. Together, this combination of field knowledge, defense-grade innovation, and real-world implementation capacity underpins the credibility and technical depth of our solution.
ssf.external_threats:
Smartflow targets the fast-growing rainwater flood resilience market, estimated at $20B globally (TAM), driven by urbanization and climate change. Within this, our Serviceable Addressable Market (SAM) is approximately $5B, focusing on high-density urban zones across the US, Europe, and Israel where infrastructure struggles to manage extreme rain events. Our initial Serviceable Obtainable Market (SOM) is $70M, as projected over 5 years, derived from direct implementation in public buildings, hospitals, logistics hubs, and infrastructure-sensitive projects.

These projections are based on hydrologists’ reports, real-time pilot validations, and economic loss data (e.g., Aquanomics, OECD), showing Smartflow can reduce flood impact by 30% per installation. Our pricing model ($2,499 HW + $99/month SaaS) aligns with both retrofit and greenfield construction ROI needs.

Our Go-To-Market strategy is rooted in professional endorsement. After being approved by most leading hydrologists in Israel, our initial deployment targets are projects currently completing construction with unresolved runoff issues. As these implementations prove successful, we expect adoption to accelerate through earlier-phase engagements (design stage), followed by expansion into underground runoff solutions for municipalities and a SaaS layer that manages above- and below-ground water data. This staged rollout ensures early traction, strong reference cases, and long-term platform stickiness.
ssf.mainstream_alternative: The mainstream alternatives currently used in the market for managing urban runoff include underground storage reservoirs, infiltration boreholes, and passive blue roofs. These systems often require complex installation and maintenance processes, especially when dealing with rooftops that host multiple mechanical systems. In contrast, our solution significantly reduces the need for large underground volumes, cuts costs, and enables a scalable and cost-effective implementation on any roof
ssf.business_opportunity:
Urban rooftops are increasingly being used for rainwater management, yet most existing solutions are either structurally invasive, too costly, or lack intelligent control. SmartFlow addresses this market gap by providing a smart, modular, and non-invasive system that works in both new and retrofit projects, enabling real-time regulation of rooftop runoff.

The main competitors in the market include:
	•	Permavoid (Polysync) – shallow rooftop retention grids with passive valves and minimal automation
	•	Wavin / Metropolder – implemented in the Resilio project (Amsterdam), which was discontinued due to performance and cost issues
	•	Polypipe Permavoid – crate-based systems with geotextile membranes requiring major rooftop adaptation
	•	Binyan Tzomeach (Israel) – local green roof integrator using rock wool and gravel layers, with no active control

Compared to these, SmartFlow offers:
	•	No structural impact – works with existing roofs
	•	Full automation and cloud-based optimization
	•	Lower cost and faster deployment
	•	Scalability – can manage multiple roofs centrally across a district

This positions SmartFlow as a unique and cost-effective solution for modern urban flood resilience.
ssf.status:
SmartFlow units are manufactured using a hybrid process: we design the full system architecture, hardware configuration, embedded software, and control algorithms in-house. All intellectual property – including system design, electronics, and software – is fully owned and developed by our team.

Final assembly and quality assurance are carried out at the production facility of Peleg Group, a strategic infrastructure partner in Israel. Peleg also handles physical installations, providing strong technical field capacity and wide coverage across the construction market.

Current production capacity is approximately 25–30 units per month, with scalable subcontractor-based manufacturing to support a projected ramp-up to 100+ units per month within a year.

As we expand, Peleg’s operational and logistics infrastructure will support both domestic and international deployments through licensing and fulfillment. In parallel, we are building relationships with engineering firms, municipal stakeholders, and integrators to ensure SmartFlow is specified early in new developments and seamlessly adopted in retrofit projects.
ssf.summary_market_of_application:
Each SmartFlow unit typically manages up to 10,000 liters of rainwater per rooftop, based on an average roof area of 500 m² and a storage height of 20 cm.
The system integrates with existing rooftop drainage and eliminates the need for dedicated reservoirs or structural modifications.
ssf.summary_market_of_application_2:
Installation takes less than 3 hours per unit and can be performed by a single technician.
The system operates at less than 4W during active mode and is designed for a 15-year service life with minimal maintenance.

SmartFlow’s hardware supports over-the-air updates, allowing remote firmware upgrade
ssf.summary_market_of_application_3:
The SmartFlow platform connects multiple buildings into a centralized dashboard, enabling real-time monitoring and coordinated stormwater control across entire neighborhoods.
Predictive AI-based regulation can reduce peak runoff discharge by up to 30%, helping cities prevent flooding and reduce stra
ssf.sei_case_study_description:
In a recent urban redevelopment project, a new residential building replaced an older, smaller structure. Due to updated municipal regulations, the new construction was required to manage on-site rainwater runoff without relying on the municipal drainage system. The physical constraints of the plot—limited space, dense surroundings, and construction limitations—made most conventional solutions impractical or prohibitively expensive.

Mainstream alternatives, such as standard blue roofs with sponge layers or shallow reservoirs, combined with extensive underground excavation and reinforcement, were evaluated. These solutions would have required deep digging and structural retaining walls, significantly increasing both cost and execution time—estimated at over 10 times the price and timeline compared to SmartFlow’s approach.

Instead, SmartFlow’s system was implemented directly on the roof without needing to excavate or modify the building’s foundations. The system, which intelligently modulates rainwater discharge in real time, enabled the project to fully comply with local stormwater regulations at a fraction of the environmental and financial cost.

From an environmental perspective, the traditional solution would have involved heavy machinery for excavation, large amounts of concrete and steel for structural work, and transportation of materials—all contributing substantially to CO₂ emissions, particulate matter, and construction waste. By contrast, SmartFlow’s plug-and-play modular system eliminated the need for earthwork and reduced material usage by over 80%, while also minimizing on-site noise and dust pollution. It required minimal maintenance, no energy input for active pumping, and operates passively based on gravity and smart flow regulation.

This case demonstrates SmartFlow’s ability to provide scalable environmental benefits in dense urban areas where traditional solutions simply aren’t viable—reducing both embodied carbon and operational impacts in the
ssf.sei_production_phase:
SmartFlow’s production phase is intentionally designed for minimal environmental impact. The system’s components are manufactured using standardized industrial processes that emphasize efficiency, material reuse, and modularity. The primary materials include recyclable polymers and stainless steel, sourced from suppliers that comply with ISO 14001 environmental standards.

Unlike traditional stormwater systems that require tons of concrete, reinforced steel, and on-site customization, SmartFlow units are prefabricated in a controlled environment, significantly reducing material waste, on-site emissions, and the carbon footprint associated with just-in-time deliveries. Each unit is compact and lightweight, which enables efficient bulk transport and minimizes fuel consumption during delivery.

Additionally, the modular design allows for batch production with little to no variation between units, enabling optimization of raw material use and quality assurance at scale. No hazardous chemicals are used during the manufacturing process, and production wastewater is minimal and fully treated before disposal.

Compared to mainstream alternatives that require custom-fabricated infrastructure and energy-intensive installation processes, SmartFlow reduces embodied carbon by an estimated 60–80% during the production and installation phase. Moreover, the solution’s low-maintenance design translates into a longer life cycle and fewer interventions over time, further reducing its total lifecycle environmental impact.

By streamlining production and prioritizing modularity and sustainability, SmartFlow sets a new benchmark in green infrastructure manufacturing and implementation.

Environmental summary:
Lifespan: SmartFlow 15 yrs vs. 10 yrs alt.
Materials per unit: ~6.5 kg vs. ~950 kg (concrete + steel).
Production energy: ~12 kWh/unit.
Operation: ~35 kWh/yr.
Water retained: ~10,000 L/event.
Peak runoff reduction: ~30%.
ssf.sei_transport:
The core components of the SmartFlow system—such as flow regulators, sensors, and structural housings—are primarily sourced as off-the-shelf industrial parts from certified manufacturers in China and Taiwan. These suppliers have been selected for their reliability, cost-effectiveness, and compliance with international environmental and quality standards.

The components are shipped by sea in consolidated containers to minimize emissions per unit and optimize logistics. Once the shipment arrives in Israel, it is transported by ground freight to our local assembly facility, where the final integration and quality assurance testing are performed under controlled conditions.

This global sourcing and local assembly model allows us to reduce manufacturing costs while maintaining high environmental performance. By avoiding energy-intensive local fabrication and leveraging existing industrial supply chains, we minimize unnecessary duplication of processes. Furthermore, sea freight—though not emission-free—offers a significantly lower carbon footprint per kilogram compared to air transport.

Throughout their life cycle, SmartFlow components are designed for minimal logistical handling: the compact, modular design allows multiple units to be shipped together with minimal packaging, reducing both volume and waste. Once assembled, the systems are distributed locally within Israel using standard ground transport, usually in bulk to project sites to further reduce emissions per installed unit.

This distribution approach ensures a balance between operational efficiency and environmental responsibility, especially when compared to traditional systems that often require heavy machinery, custom parts, and multiple shipments per site.
ssf.sei_use_phase:
SmartFlow is designed to operate with minimal resource consumption. The system uses only a few milliamperes of electricity, supplied by low-voltage connections or, optionally, by integrated solar panels. There is no need for active pumping or continuous monitoring, making SmartFlow one of the most energy-efficient solutions available in its category.

In terms of water usage, SmartFlow does not consume water but rather manages and redirects rainwater in real-time. In planned deployments, the collected rainwater can be reused for secondary purposes such as irrigation, toilet flushing, or groundwater recharge—further reducing the building’s environmental footprint.

An optional pre-filtration module is available, enabling removal of debris and sediments before the water is discharged or reused. This prevents clogging in infiltration wells and maximizes the long-term efficiency of the system without requiring external cleaning water or frequent interventions.

In contrast, mainstream alternatives such as sponge-based blue roofs or underground retention systems often require periodic maintenance involving water-intensive cleaning, electrical pumping systems, or vacuuming of silt deposits—resulting in significantly higher operational energy and water usage over time.
ssf.sei_disposal_phase:
At the end of its life cycle, SmartFlow is fully recyclable and/or reusable. All components used in the system are made from recyclable polymers, stainless steel, and standard electronics, none of which include hazardous substances or restricted materials under current green standards.

The system is currently undergoing certification for a national Green Label in Israel, validating its environmentally responsible material choices and end-of-life recyclability. Since the modules are assembled without permanent bonding or chemical adhesives, disassembly is straightforward and supports both partial reuse and full material separation.

Compared to conventional alternatives, which often include concrete structures or composite materials that are not recyclable and typically end up in landfills, SmartFlow significantly reduces waste generation at disposal. Its circular design approach aligns with modern sustainability goals and waste reduction policies.
ssf.ei_energy_usage_1: SmartFlow reduces GHG emissions by replacing flood pumps and excavation equipment with passive, gravity-based drainage — saving up to 35 kWh/year per unit.
ssf.ei_energy_usage_2: Each SmartFlow unit avoids up to 80% of the embodied carbon compared to conventional concrete-based retention tanks and infrastructure.
ssf.ei_water_savings_1: Each SmartFlow unit retains up to 10,000 liters of rainwater per storm and enables on-site reuse, reducing load on municipal systems.
ssf.ei_water_savings_2: By filtering and regulating runoff, SmartFlow reduces sediment pollution and improves water reuse potential without added energy or chemicals.
ssf.economic:
The SmartFlow solution offers a highly cost-effective and scalable approach to urban stormwater management, especially for flat roof environments.

Price & Payback Time:
SmartFlow costs approximately ₪15,000 per 100m² of rooftop, with a typical installation including 4 systems per roof, totaling ₪60,000. Annual maintenance costs are low—₪1,200 per year—thanks to the system’s simple and robust design. In contrast, the mainstream alternative—commonly a blue roof with a shallow basin and complex drainage infrastructure—costs around ₪200,000 for the same roof area. The SmartFlow system offers a near-immediate return on investment (ROI), as clients are often required by regulation to install a drainage solution anyway, and SmartFlow is significantly cheaper and easier to install.

Installation & Maintenance:
The system installs 10x faster than traditional solutions and requires minimal maintenance. Its plug-and-play design allows for rapid deployment with minimal skilled labor and no need for heavy structural changes. Unlike the complex systems used today, SmartFlow is built to be resilient and easily accessible for inspections or updates.

Flood Mitigation & Long-Term Value:
The system has been shown to reduce water accumulation height by ~30% during extreme rainfall events. As seen in the supporting documentation, each percent reduction in water height has quantifiable value in euros, depending on building density and flood risk. Therefore, even one storm event where SmartFlow reduces damage or liability may return the investment many times over.

Lifespan & Durability:
The system has an expected lifespan of 10+ years before any hardware upgrade or replacement is necessary. It is designed to withstand harsh environmental conditions and is suitable for long-term urban infrastructure use.

Real-World Deployment:
SmartFlow has been deployed in multiple real-estate projects in Tel Aviv and Kfar Saba through a leading contractor under Israel’s Tama 38 urban renewal framework. These installations have validated the performance, ease of use, and integration into existing drainage networks.

Regulatory Incentives & Municipal Benefits:
SmartFlow is in the final stages of receiving a national green building label, which will earn contractors sustainability points during permit applications. Additionally, discussions are ongoing with major municipalities (including Tel Aviv, Herzliya, and Bat Yam) to provide property tax incentives for private developers who install SmartFlow. The system also allows cities to digitally monitor runoff volume from private parcels, which is a powerful tool for public planning and flood prevention.
ssf.economic_intensity_detail:
Currently, the SmartFlow system requires an upfront investment that covers most of the total lifecycle cost (~84%), due to the physical components and installation. Therefore, we selected category D.

However, we are actively working on evolving our pricing model: in future deployments, we intend to reduce the initial capital requirement below 50% of the total cost and shift toward a higher annual service fee. This transition will be enabled once we achieve sufficient operational cash flow and production scale, making the solution even more accessible to municipalities and developers.
ssf.ef_directly_cheaper_1: The SmartFlow rooftop solution costs ₪15,000 per 100 m², compared to approximately ₪200,000 for conventional blue roof systems – a direct saving of over 85% for both municipalities and contractors.
ssf.ef_directly_cheaper_2: SmartFlow installs within hours, not days, requires no heavy machinery, and includes a built-in dashboard for real-time runoff monitoring – making it the simplest, most cost-effective way for builders and city planners to meet flood mitigation regulations

implementationstories.title: Rainwater compliance solved in a fast, affordable and non-invasive way
implementationstories.description_client: A new residential building in central Tel Aviv was constructed on the site of a demolished old house. The local municipality required compliance with new rainwater retention regulations. Due to structural and space constraints, traditional solutions such as underground tanks were not feasible. SmartFlow was the only affordable and technically applicable system that could be installed quickly at the end of the construction phase – without redesign or excavation.
implementationstories.description_result: Without SmartFlow, the project faced regulatory rejection due to lack of feasible drainage. The client completed the installation in half a day and resolved the issue with a $30K investment – enabling project approval and avoiding major redesign costs.

ssf.other_pool_restriction: WILHELMSEN SHIPS SERVICE, WILHELMSEN CHEMICALS, DREW MARINE, MARICHEM MARIGASES, MARISOL, VECOM MARINE CHEMICALS
ssf.name: Purewave Pipe Cleaner
ssf.one_sentence_description: An environmentally friendly chemical that removes uric scale and fat from pipes below vacuum toilets.
ssf.public_short_description: Toilet pipes on vessels are highly susceptible for calcification. Purewave Pipe cleaner removes these calcifications in a simple, efficient and gentle way. Using only biodegradable ingredients Purewave Pipe Cleaner opens and prevents clogged toilets, without damaging pipes or the environment.
ssf.environmental_benefit:
Over time, uric scale builds up in the pipes below vacuum toilets, reducing the diameter of the pipes, which again causing clogging of pipes. The solution is either to replace the pipes, or to use acid to remove the scale.
Most current products for removing uric scale are based on phosphoric or sulfamic acid. These are both found to be harmful to aquatic life.
The main ingredient in our solution is citric acid, which is biodegradable and not harmful to the environment.
ssf.economical_benefit:
Experiencing clogged pipes can be expensive.
For owners of passenger vessels, having problems with toilets can be a stinky thing that can be costly to their reputation, as well as the cost and practical issues of taking vessel out of operations due to clogged toilet pipes.
Replacing pipes or having plumbers come and unclog them can be very costly for a large vessel.
By applying a small amount of Purewave Pipe Cleaner in each toilet once a week, buildup of uric scale in the pipes is prevented. Our customers tell us that their business case is based on the amount they save on not having to unclog pipes on a annual/biannual basis.
ssf.ss_title: Removing uric scale and fat in pipes onboard MS Berg of Brim Explorer
ssf.ss_description:
The expedition vessel MS Berg from Brim Explorer followed the recommended guidelines for using Unitor Gamazyme TDS but still experienced uric scale and fat buildup in the pipes beneath the vacuum toilets.
When we started the test, there was a layer of approximately 0.5 cm of uric scale in the pipes. 

After 10 days of applying 0.2 liter of Purewave Pipe Cleaner in each toilet, only minor traces of uric scale remained in the pipes.

Based on their experience with Purewave Pipe Cleaner, they instantly changed supplier.

Customer Comment:
"I must say, the effect was quite impressive."
– Simon Rognskog, Maintenance Chief, Brim Explorer
ssf.ss_case_study_impact:
Brim Explorer runs a fleet of hybrid-electric expedition vessels taking tourists on short cruises in the fjords of Norway. Having stinky or clogged toilets can impact their reputation as a tour operator.
By switching from their existing supplier to Purewave Pipe Cleaner, they can now have clean pipes and no more smelly toilets using an environmentally friendly product that works better and costs about the same.
ssf.technical_aspects:
Uric scale is a hard, chalky deposit that forms in plumbing systems, especially in urinals and vacuum toilets. It primarily consists of uric acid crystals, which are by-products of urine, and other minerals like calcium and magnesium that are naturally present in water. Over time, these substances precipitate out of the liquid and adhere to the walls of pipes and fixtures.

In vacuum toilets, commonly used on ships, the deposits form faster because there is less water to flush away residues.

Build-up of uric scale causes two main problems: 
- Clogged pipes: The build-up narrow pipe diameters, reducing flow efficiency and causing blockages.
- Foul odours: Deposits can trap organic material, leading to unpleasant smells over time.

Pilot customers have told us that fat deposits are also a cause of blockages in the pipes. Therefore, we also needed the product to dissolve fat.

The main ingredients in Purewave Pipe Cleaner are citric acid (which dissolves uric scale) and an alcohol ethoxylate (which dissolves fat).

The solution is not patented, rather we keep the recipe a company secret to protect our business.

We have done tests onboard several vessels to ascertain the efficiency of our solution. The dosing that we have been testing as been:
- For vessels with existing uric scale in pipes: 0.2 litres in each toilet twice a day for 10 days to remove scale (totalling 4 litres per toilet over ten days).
- For vessels with cleaned pipes: 0.2 litres in each toilet once a week to avoid new build-up of uric scale (totalling about 10 litres per toilet per year).

Attached are reports and case studies from testing onboard vessels.
ssf.human_assets:
The main inventor of the product is Sølvi Hjelmeland, the founder of Purewave AS. She has previously launched a similar product in her first start-up, which succeeded in developing a solution that gained Nordic Swan Ecolabel approval and commercial customers. The Purewave Pipe Cleaner is a new and improved solution based on the experiences from the first product.

A key contributor in developing the solution has been Jarle Bergli, the General Manager of Kjemihuset Effekt AS, a chemical blending company based in Østfold, Norway.

The CEO of Purewave AS, Harald Lundestad, has been 18 years with Wilhelmsen Ships Service, the market leader in marine chemicals. He has extended experience both on the sales side and the distribution operations side of the marine chemicals business. In addition, he has also been part of successfully building up a maritime software start-up from scratch as employee number two. He has a very good understanding of what it takes to build a successful business in the maritime industry.

We have also had support from Torghatten Nord, a ferry company in Norway for testing the solution onboard their vessels. Later we were also able test the solution onboard vessels of Brim Explorer AS and The Fjords DA.
ssf.external_threats:
Jets Group, the marked leader on vacuum sanitary systems, reports that they have installed over 60,000 vacuum pumps onboard vessels. Evac, another major provider, has completed more than 20,000 marine projects.  Based on this, we can assume that there is a minimum of 80,000 vessels with vacuum toilets onboard.

The number of toilets can range from one single toilet onboard a small pleasure craft to thousands of toilets onboard large cruise vessels. There is no available figure for number of vacuum toilets onboard vessels, but assuming an average of 5-10 toilets per vessel, we get a number of around 400,000-800,000 vacuum toilets.

Assuming a spend of between EUR 100-200 per toilet per year on different toilet descalers and pipe cleaners, we arrive at a TAM of EUR 200-800 million.

With our current logistics set-up, we can deliver to any port in Europe. Outside Europe, freight expenses would be too high and we would not be price competitive, except for large orders. Assuming that 25% of vessels are in European waters, the SAM would be EUR 50-200 million.

Our go-to-market strategy focuses primarily on passenger, cruise and superyachts. These vessels have many toilets onboard, and having clogged pipes or toilets with foul odour are unacceptable onboard these type of vessels. They are also operating out of a few key ports, which makes logistics easier.

In the world, there are about 1000 large cruise vessels and ferries, 2000 mid-size ferries and passenger vessels, and 2300 superyachts. About half of these are operating in or are controlled by European companies and can be serviced by our company. Our realistic mid-term SOM target is to get a 10% market share of these vessels, which based on our current pricing and estimated spend of pipe cleaner per vessel would equate to revenues of about EUR 10 million.

Our value proposition is a product that works better than the mainstream alternative, costs about the same, and is environmentally friendly.
ssf.mainstream_alternative:
The mainstream alternative used by most vessels is Unitor Gamazyme TDS, delivered by Wilhelmsen Ships Service, the market leader in marine chemicals. This product does not work so well, so once a year, or once every two years, the vessels need to apply Unitor Vacuum Pipe Cleaner to remove uric scale.
The main active ingredients in Unitor Gamazyme TDS are citric acid, sulfamic acid and sodium carbonate, while in Unitor Vacuum Pipe Cleaner, the main active ingredient is sulfamic acid.
ssf.business_opportunity:
Other players in the market includes:
- Uriclean Concentrate from Vecom Marine. Main active ingredients: Phosphoric acid, orthophosphoric acid, hydrogen cloride and isotridecanol.
- Marisol PC from Marisol. Main active ingredient: Phosphoric acid.
- Jets Descale Jel from Jets Group: Main active ingredient: Sulfamic acid.
- Hepburn Bio Scale Zapper from Hepburn Bio: Marketed as biodegradable and phosphate free based on organic acids, but exact content unknown to us.

Neither of these products alternatives dissolve the combination of both uric scale and fat, like Purewave Pipe Cleaner does.

We are in the process of applying for the Nordic Swan Ecolabel, which have stricter environmental requirements than EU's Ecolabel. Products containing phosphoric acid or sulfamic acid will never be awarded this ecolabel.

Our product differentiates itself from the competition by only containing only biodegradable ingredients that do not harm marine life or contribute to eutrophication.

In addition, our tests have found that our product works better than the competitors' products.
ssf.status:
We are still in a start-up phase, only having established our company in July of 2024. In this short time, we have managed to get one expedition company, three ferry companies and one cruise company as customers. These have a total combined fleet of about 150 vessels.

Currently, we are blending all our products at a facility near Oslo, Norway. This facility can produce tens of thousands of litres per day of our product. This is far beyond what is required from our side, as our largest order size on any day to date has been 600 litres.

We distribute our products by using freight forwarders to arrange transport from our blending facility to the port the vessel is calling, or to the customers' designated warehouse. This mode of operations is very scalable.

As sales volumes increase, we may consider blending closer to key ports where delivery volumes are high. We have already identified a potential partner in Florida, and will also consider blending in Spain and Greece.

We are also in the process of engaging sales partners in locations where decision makers on technical maintenance of vessels within our target segments are present.

Purewave is a community member of The Ocean Opportunity Lab (TOOL),  a global resource network that enables efficient and broad access to local representatives and partners in the value chain, including start-ups, capital, accelerators/incubators, and industrial customers/partners.
ssf.summary_market_of_application: Removes uric scale and fat in vacuum toilet pipes
ssf.summary_market_of_application_3: 10 litres of Purewave Pipe Cleaner is enough to maintain clean pipes in a toilet for a whole year,
ssf.sei_case_study_description:
A large cruise vessel may have about 5000 toilets onboard. (One in each passenger cabin, a few hundred in the public areas and five hundred to a thousand in the crew cabins).

The recommended dosing of Unitor Gamazyme TDS is one 50 gram sachet in each toilet every week. In a year, this equates to 260,000 PVA sachets (a source of microplastic) and 2-4 metric tons of sulfamic acid released into the ocean.

Since Unitor Gamazyme TDS is not 100% efficient, the vessel will typically need to do acid cleaning of the pipes to remove uric scale once every couple of years using Unitor Vacuum Pipe Cleaner. The recommended dosing is 1.2-1.4 litres per 8-10 toilets per day. Depending on the thickness of the uric scale, this will take 5-10 days.

This acid cleaning treatment will add an additional 200-500 kg of sulfamic acid to the ocean environment.

Using Purewave Pipe Cleaner, one the other hand, does not lead to the release of any harmful chemicals to the ocean.

Purewave Pipe Cleaner enables vessel owners to extend the lifetime of existing pipes, by reducing the wear and tear, and the need for replacing clogged pipes.
ssf.sei_production_phase:
Purewave Pipe Cleaner contains between 30 and 60 percent citric acid and between 1 and 5 percent ethoxylated hexan-1-ol.
Unitor Gamazyme TDS contains between 30 and 60 percent citric acid, between 15 and 30 percent sulfamic acid and between 5 and 15 percent sodium nitrate.
Unitor Vacuum Pipe Cleaner contains  7 percent sulfamic acid.

Attached is a document showing competing alternatives and their composition.

The main difference is that our solution mainly contains citric acid, while the mainstream alternative uses sulfamic acid.

Citric acid production uses renewable, natural substrates like sugar or molasses, often sourced from agricultural crops, and relies on biological fermentation, which is generally considered environmentally friendly.
Sulfamic acid production uses synthetic chemicals like urea and sulphur trioxide or chlorosulfonic acid, which  are derived from non-renewable resources (e.g., petroleum derivatives), which can have a larger environmental footprint.

Citric acid production is significantly more environmentally friendly than sulfamic acid production. The reliance on renewable resources, biological processes, and biodegradable by-products makes citric acid production sustainable and less harmful to the environment. In contrast, sulfamic acid production involves synthetic chemicals, higher energy consumption, and potentially hazardous by-products, which pose greater environmental challenges.
ssf.sei_transport:
Even though we do not know the details of how competing solutions are sourced and distributed, we can assume that they are very similar.

Both Purewave Pipe Cleaner and Unitor Gamazyme TDS are made using raw materials sourced from producers in Europe. These raw materials are transported on trucks to the blending facilities in Norway.

After blending, the products are forwarded to the port for delivery to vessels. If the distance is short, this will be done onboard trucks. For more distant locations, this will be done with a combination of sea transport and trucking.

At Purewave, we are very conscious about the environmental footprint of our product distribution. To minimise transportation, we are therefore encouraging our customers to take delivery of our products once a year only. Our standard delivery contract involves one single delivery per year.

In addition, we deliver to multiple vessels in the same port with the shipment, if possible.
ssf.sei_use_phase: The use phase for Purewave Pipe Cleaner and the mainstream alternative is very similar.  They are both dosed into the toilet bowl and their use do not consume any resources.
ssf.sei_disposal_phase: Our main ingredient, citric acid, is delivered in 25 kg multi-layered paper bags with an inner plastic lining. These bags are delivered for recycling in accordance with local regulations in Oslo, Norway.
ssf.ei_biodiversity_1: Does not contain any ingredients that harm marine life
ssf.ei_biodiversity_2: Does not contain any ingredients that contribute to eutrophication
ssf.ei_air_pollution_1: Does not contain any toxic ingredients
ssf.economic:
Our main selling point is that our product costs about the same as Unitor Gamazyme TDS (the mainstream alternative), but is more environmentally friendly.

Though we do not have the exact price each ship owner is paying for Unitor Gamazyme TDS, prices we have been able to obtain has ranged from EUR 285 - EUR 349 for a packet of 100 sachets. The recommended dosing is one sachet per toilet per week, which gives a cost per toilet per year of EUR 148 - EUR 181.

We have been selling our solution at an average price of EUR 427 for a 25 litre pail. The recommended dosing is 0.2 litre per toilet per week, which gives a cost per toilet per year of EUR 178.

This means that the price of our solution is slightly on the higher side, however, two separate ferry companies that we have spoken to, say that they spend a considerable amount on acid cleaning of pipes every couple of years and that this forms part of their business case when considering switching to our solution.

One of the companies did not want to share the cost of acid cleaning with us, but the other company said that they use an external company to perform this at an estimated cost of EUR 8,000 per treatment per vessel. This vessel had about 25 toilets onboard, which equals a cost of EUR 160 per toilet per year. This cost is completely avoided when using our solution, which makes us cost competitive in the long run.
ssf.economic_intensity_detail:
The Purewave Pipe Cleaner is a consumable that you purchase on a regular basis to keep your vacuum toilet pipes free of uric scale and fat, and in working order.

We are not sure if capital intensity is a relevant measure here, since it is this a recurring expense and not an upfront investment. The cost of applying the pipe cleaner should perhaps be counted as an operating cost and seen relative to the investment of the vacuum toilet system, where the annual cost of applying the pipe cleaner would be somewhere around 10% of the initial investment in the vacuum toilet system.
ssf.ef_total_cost_1: With only one weekly dosing of 0.2 litres of Purewave Pipe Cleaner in each toilet the pipes are kept clean from uric scale and fat.
ssf.ef_total_cost_2: Purewave Pipe Cleaner is so efficient that there is no need for bi-annual acid cleaning of pipes.

implementationstories.title: Removing uric scale and fat in pipes onboard MS Berg of Brim Explorer
implementationstories.description_client: The expedition vessel MS Berg from Brim Explorer followed the recommended guidelines for using Unitor Gamazyme TDS but still experienced uric scale and fat buildup in the pipes beneath the vacuum toilets. When we started the test, there was a layer of approximately 0.5 cm of uric scale in the pipes. After 10 days of applying 0.2 liter of Purewave Pipe Cleaner in each toilet, only minor traces of uric scale remained in the pipes. Based on their experience with Purewave Pipe Cleaner, they instantly changed supplier.
implementationstories.description_result:
Brim Explorer runs a fleet of hybrid-electric expedition vessels taking tourists on short cruises in the fjords of Norway. Having stinky or clogged toilets can impact their reputation as a tour operator.
By switching from their existing supplier to Purewave Pipe Cleaner, they can now have clean pipes and no more smelly toilets using an environmentally friendly product that works better and costs about the same.

solutions_of_the_month.one_sentence_description: Aircraft tailored for pilot training with a hybrid-electric powertrain and a fully electric powertrain option
solutions_of_the_month.intro: Smartflyer is developing a hybrid-electric aircraft designed to make flying quieter, cleaner, and more efficient. Unlike traditional planes, our aircraft combines an electric motor with a fuel-powered range extender, reducing noise by up to 60% and CO₂ emissions by over 50%. It’s built for everyday use in pilot training, eco-tourism, and regional mobility—where sustainability is urgently needed. With a range of over 800 km and seating for four, Smartflyer offers a practical and certifiable solution for the general aviation market. Its modular design allows for easy maintenance, upgrades, and future integration of alternative power sources such as hydrogen or fully electric systems. The highly efficient rear-mounted propeller, positioned in a pusher configuration, minimizes aerodynamic drag and cabin noise while maximizing overall propulsion efficiency.

ssf.other_pool_restriction: PIPISTREL, PILATUS AIRCRAFT LTD., DIAMOND AIRCRAFT, AURA AERO, H55
ssf.name: Smartflyer SF-1
ssf.one_sentence_description: Aircraft tailored for pilot training with a hybrid-electric powertrain and a fully electric powertrain option
ssf.public_short_description: Smartflyer is developing a hybrid-electric aircraft designed to make flying quieter, cleaner, and more efficient. Unlike traditional planes, our aircraft combines an electric motor with a fuel-powered range extender, reducing noise by up to 60% and CO₂ emissions by up to 50%. It’s built for everyday use in pilot training, eco-tourism, and regional mobility—where sustainability is urgently needed. With a range of over 800 km and seating for four, Smartflyer offers a practical and certifiable solution for the training and general aviation market. Its modular design allows for easy maintenance, upgrades, and future integration of alternative power sources such as hydrogen or fully electric systems. The highly efficient rear-mounted propeller, positioned in a pusher configuration, minimizes aerodynamic drag and cabin noise while maximizing overall propulsion efficiency.
ssf.environmental_benefit: The main environmental benefit of Smartflyer’s hybrid-electric aircraft lies in its significant reduction of both emissions and noise. By combining an electric motor with a range-extending generator, the aircraft reduces CO₂ emissions by over 50% compared to conventional piston-engine planes. Additionally, the quiet electric propulsion system lowers noise pollution by up to 60%, which is especially important for training operations near populated areas. Thanks to its hybrid configuration, the aircraft can operate in full-electric mode during noise-sensitive phases—such as takeoff and landing near airports—providing a major advantage for community acceptance and regulatory compliance. Its modular architecture allows for future integration of zero-emission energy sources like hydrogen or batteries as technology evolves, ensuring long-term sustainability.
ssf.economical_benefit: The main economic benefit of Smartflyer’s hybrid-electric solution lies in its significantly lower direct operating costs. By shifting the primary propulsion load to the electric motor and using the combustion engine only as a range extender, engine wear is drastically reduced, leading to lower maintenance frequency and costs. In addition, fuel consumption is cut by up to 50%, generating substantial savings over time—especially for flight schools and operators with high hourly usage. Another key advantage is the modular design of the system: the combustion unit and the aircraft’s front section (“nose module”) can be maintained independently from the airframe. This allows operators to rotate different modules and continue flying with minimal downtime, improving fleet availability and maximizing aircraft utilization. Together, these factors enable a more cost-effective and efficient operation compared to conventional training or touring aircraft.
ssf.ss_grants_recognition: Spezialfinanzierung Luftverkehr (SFLV, Sustainability financing of The Federal Office of Civil Aviation (FOCA) Switzerland)
ssf.technical_aspects:
The Smartflyer SF-1 is a hybrid-electric aircraft featuring a high-wing configuration combined with a conventional tail assembly. The aircraft employs a standard horizontal stabilizer mounted at the rear fuselage and a single vertical stabilizer, supporting the electric propulsion system located at the top of the fin.

The propulsion system consists of an electric motor driving a propeller installed at the top of the vertical stabilizer, operating in a tractor (puller) configuration. This configuration offers approximately 25% greater aerodynamic efficiency compared to conventional nose-mounted tractor systems. This improvement results from the relatively undisturbed airflow and the reduction of fuselage-induced drag, enhancing overall cruise efficiency.

Electrical energy is stored in modular lithium-ion battery packs integrated within the wing structure. Battery placement ensures optimized load distribution and maintains a relatively high center of gravity, counteracting the pitching moments caused by the high-mounted propeller thrust line during power application. This configuration stabilizes longitudinal flight dynamics across varying flight phases.

A combustion engine acts as a range extender, operating a generator that provides electrical power to either the propulsion motor or the batteries during flight. The combustion engine is mechanically decoupled from the propeller and runs at a constant optimal operating point, thereby increasing efficiency and reducing mechanical complexity and wear.

A centralized Power Distribution Unit (PDU) manages real-time energy flow, dynamically balancing between battery discharge, generator output, and energy recovery while maintaining system redundancy via dual high-voltage bus systems.

The Smartflyer SF-1's airframe structure utilizes high-performance carbon fiber composites for the fuselage and wings, achieving high strength-to-weight ratios, enhanced fatigue resistance, and smooth aerodynamic surfaces. The wing structure incorporates two dedicated C-spars, which provide the necessary structural stability while simultaneously integrating the embedded battery packs without compromising the aerodynamic profile or load-bearing capacity of the wing. 

The cockpit accommodates four seats in a side-by-side configuration. The pilot’s seat is positioned ahead of the wing’s leading edge, enabling excellent all-around visibility and eliminating the visual obstructions typically associated with high-wing aircraft during turning maneuvers.

Independent cooling systems for the propulsion motor, batteries, and range extender ensure optimal thermal management without thermal interaction between systems, supporting operational safety and efficiency across all environmental conditions.

A distinctive feature of the SF-1 is its modular airframe design, specifically the independently removable nose section. This modularity allows future upgrades of the propulsion system—such as integration of alternative hybrid modules, hydrogen-based propulsion, or advanced battery-electric systems—without requiring major structural modifications to the main airframe. This design approach ensures long-term adaptability and investment protection as technology advances.

The high-wing configuration provides natural roll stability, good downward visibility, and operational robustness for semi-prepared airfield use. The fixed landing gear system is designed to absorb typical loads from a variety of surface types. Flight controls are conventionally mechanically actuated, preserving intuitive pilot handling characteristics.

The Smartflyer SF-1 is developed and constructed according to the EASA CS-23 certification standard for small aeroplanes, ensuring compliance with recognized European safety, performance, and airworthiness regulations. This certification basis supports a broad operational envelope including pilot training and potential light commercial applications.
ssf.human_assets:
The development of the Smartflyer SF-1 is driven by a highly experienced internal team supported by a strong network of industry and research partners. The Board of Directors and the extended management team collectively bring over 120 years of flying experience, 40 years of electrical engineering expertise, 80 years of entrepreneurial knowledge, and 80 years of financial experience.

Within Smartflyer AG, the engineering and development team includes specialists in electric systems, CAD design, structural engineering, mechanical systems, flight deck development, and hybrid-electric system integration. The leadership team and technical staff have a proven background in aviation projects and complex engineering developments.

In addition to internal expertise, Smartflyer maintains an active presence in the broader aviation and innovation community. The company is a co-organizer of the annual Electrify-in event in Switzerland — the only European event specifically focused on electric aviation — and is a member of several strategic networks including the Swiss Aerospace Cluster, Aerolite, AeroFEM, and Emrax. These affiliations enable continuous exchange of knowledge, access to key supplier ecosystems, and alignment with the latest industry research.

Smartflyer has also built a solid intellectual property base, including configuration designs, CAD documentation, full system descriptions, and modular energy storage concepts. Patent applications are under preparation to protect key innovations.

To support the future certification process, Smartflyer collaborates closely with the Swiss Federal Office of Civil Aviation (FOCA), particularly with the STIL division, ensuring alignment with regulatory frameworks and certification pathways.

This combination of internal technical excellence, operational aviation experience, strong external partnerships, and proactive regulatory engagement provides a credible foundation for the development and future evolution of the SF-1.
ssf.external_threats:
Smartflyer addresses the growing demand for sustainable training aircraft with its hybrid-electric SF-1. With over 620,000 new pilots needed by 2043 (Airbus/Boeing) and an aging fleet of SEP aircraft, the market urgently requires modern, low-emission solutions (further information for chapter 4.2 can be found in the attached document). 

Based on pilot demand forecasts and Smartflyer’s own data analysis from major flight schools, the total addressable market (TAM) is estimated at approx. 13,500 SEP training aircraft over the next 20 years. This figure is derived by dividing the projected number of new pilots (over 620,000) by the number of pilots typically trained per aircraft per year. Based on data gathered by Smartflyer from leading flight academies, one training aircraft supports 5 to 10 cadets annually. With expected service lives of 10 to 15 years in high-utilization environments (1,000–1,400 flight hours/year), this yields a robust estimate of global aircraft demand.

The serviceable addressable market (SAM) for Europe—Smartflyer’s initial focus due to the EASA certification path—is around 3,100 aircraft. Given minimal competition in the hybrid-electric segment and strong policy support, Smartflyer considers a 5–10 % market share (SOM) realistic, equivalent to 155 to 310 aircraft over 20 years.

Europe is uniquely attractive for market entry due to ambitious climate goals, noise and emissions regulations, and programs such as Clean Aviation. Flight academies are under pressure to modernize fleets, and Smartflyer’s clean, efficient technology meets this need.

The go-to-market strategy includes demo programs with schools, presence at key aviation events, leasing and support partnerships, and ESG-focused communications. The SF-1 offers up to 50 % lower operating costs, low maintenance, and high availability through a modular hybrid-electric propulsion system. Smartflyer is well positioned to serve a market in urgent need of sustainable transformation.
ssf.mainstream_alternative: The mainstream alternative to the SF-1 in the training aircraft market is the use of conventional single-engine piston aircraft with combustion engines, such as the Cessna 172 and Piper Archer. These aircraft are still widely used in flight training but are based on outdated designs from the 1950s and 60s. Despite updates, their propulsion systems and aerodynamics have changed little, resulting in high emissions, noise, and operating costs that no longer meet modern sustainability standards.
ssf.business_opportunity:
Current alternatives to the Smartflyer SF-1 in the training aircraft market fall into three main categories: conventional combustion-engine aircraft, fully electric aircraft, and early-stage hybrid concepts.

Conventional combustion-engine aircraft like the Cessna 172 and Piper Archer are still the standard in flight training. While widely available and well-supported, these aircraft are based on outdated designs from the 1950s and many rely on leaded aviation fuel (AVGAS 100LL), contributing to environmental pollution. They are also expensive to operate and maintain, making them increasingly unfit for modern training needs.

Fully electric aircraft, such as the Pipistrel Velis Electro, offer zero local emissions and very low noise levels. The Velis is the first EASA-certified electric aircraft and represents a major step forward in sustainable aviation. However, its practical use is limited: with an endurance of about 50 minutes plus reserve and only two seats, it cannot support the demands of full-scale flight training programs. Additionally, the limited charging infrastructure at many airfields restricts operational flexibility.

Hybrid-electric aircraft promise to combine the best of both worlds, but current models remain in early development. Projects like the VoltAero Cassio or Pipistrel Panthera Hybrid are still uncertified, delayed or not tailored for the training segment. Many retrofit existing airframes rather than offering purpose-built solutions, resulting in performance and integration compromises.

Smartflyer SF-1 stands alone as the only hybrid-electric aircraft designed from scratch for training. Its modular system allows switching between hybrid and full-electric mode, enabling both flexibility and future-proofing. It operates efficiently even at airports without charging infrastructure, while offering significantly lower emissions, costs, and noise. This makes the SF-1 the most practical and scalable option for sustainable flight training.
ssf.status:
Smartflyer is currently preparing to scale its hybrid-electric aircraft project by focusing on industrial partnerships and alternative distribution models. To enable serial production and accelerate the EASA CS-23 certification process, Smartflyer is actively seeking a partner from the aviation industry. The objective is to leverage existing infrastructure, experience, and capacity to reduce time to market and meet regulatory requirements more efficiently.

To support market entry, particularly in the flight training sector, Smartflyer is in contact with leasing companies such as Green Aerolease. The aim is to offer flight schools an operational package that includes aircraft leasing, support, and maintenance services. This approach provides customers with financing flexibility and lowers the entry barrier for transitioning to hybrid-electric aircraft.

The SF-1 aircraft is designed with a modular propulsion system that allows for flexible operation and future technical upgrades. While the initial focus is on the training segment, the system architecture also allows for potential scaling into other aviation markets. One example under consideration is the development of a larger aircraft based on the same hybrid-electric principles—referred to as the Smartflyer eLiner. This concept would target the business and regional aviation segment with 6 to 10 seats. At present, this is a future option being evaluated, not an active development program.

The scale-up strategy is structured around gradual market expansion, beginning in Europe due to alignment with environmental regulations and certification processes. Further growth will depend on international certification (e.g., FAA) and the establishment of manufacturing capacity through industrial cooperation. Additional market segments, including general aviation and commercial light transport, are part of the long-term perspective.
ssf.summary_market_of_application:
Hybrid instead of fully electric:
The Smartflyer SF-1 uses an electric motor powered by either batteries or a small combustion engine (range extender). This allows a flight range of up to 800 km—even from airfields without charging infrastructure.
ssf.summary_market_of_application_2:
Modular power unit:
The SF-1 features a swappable energy module. In just 15 minutes, operators can switch between battery and hybrid systems. This reduces downtime and adapts to available energy sources without complex maintenance. A future fuel cell version is feasible.
ssf.summary_market_of_application_3:
Quieter and more efficient:
Unlike conventional aircraft, the SF-1's propeller is mounted on the tail. Combined with the electric motor, this reduces noise by up to 60%. The configuration also improves aerodynamic efficiency by avoiding disturbed airflow along the fuselage.
ssf.sei_case_study_description:
The Smartflyer SF-1 is a four-seat hybrid-electric aircraft developed for flight training. As a comparison model, the Piper Archer TX is used—a widely deployed trainer powered by a Lycoming IO-360 engine. This engine runs on AVGAS 100LL, a leaded aviation fuel still commonly used in general aviation.  

The Archer TX consumes up to 38 liters of AVGAS per flight hour, which corresponds to approximately 85–90 kg of CO₂ emissions per hour, depending on flight profile and conditions (for figures see atteched file). In addition to carbon dioxide, combustion of AVGAS 100LL releases airborne lead particles, which contribute to pollution and are associated with health risks for nearby communities.

In contrast, the Smartflyer SF-1 uses a hybrid-electric propulsion system with a modular energy unit located in the aircraft’s nose. It can operate either fully electric—with zero emissions at the point of use—or in hybrid mode using a range extender. In hybrid mode, fuel consumption and CO₂ emissions are reduced by more than 50% compared to conventional piston aircraft.

Assuming 1,000 flight hours annually—a typical value in flight school operations—the SF-1 avoids approximately 35–40 metric tons of CO₂ emissions per year relative to the Archer TX. Lead emissions are fully eliminated.

Noise emissions are also significantly reduced. The SF-1’s electric drivetrain and tail-mounted propeller reduce sound levels by up to 60%, improving conditions for instructors, students, and surrounding communities, and enabling quieter operations at sensitive airfields.

The aircraft’s modular system allows future upgrades, such as the integration of fuel cells, without structural redesign. This supports long-term adaptability to evolving energy systems.

This case demonstrates that compared to a conventional training aircraft like the Piper Archer TX, the Smartflyer SF-1 offers substantial reductions in emissions and noise while maintaining full suitability for flight training use.
ssf.sei_production_phase:
The Smartflyer SF-1 and Piper Archer TX represent fundamentally different material approaches. As detailed in the document “Case Study Environmental Impact – Smartflyer SF-1”, the SF-1 is constructed entirely from carbon fiber composites, with an estimated 550–600 kg used for the fuselage, wings, and tail. This lightweight structure improves aerodynamic performance but involves a more energy-intensive production process. In contrast, the Piper Archer TX follows a traditional all-aluminum airframe design, using approximately 600–620 kg of aluminum alloys.

The SF-1 integrates a hybrid-electric propulsion system, requiring approximately 200 kg of lithium-ion batteries and 30–35 kg of copper for motor windings and high-voltage systems. The Archer TX does not include electric components and contains only about 10–12 kg of copper, mainly for avionics. Both aircraft use steel for reinforcement and landing gear structures—30–40 kg in the SF-1 and 60–70 kg in the Archer TX. The Archer TX also includes small amounts of titanium (1–2 kg) and lead (5–10 kg), which are not present in the SF-1.

Glass and acrylics (30–35 kg) as well as rubber/plastics (20–35 kg) are used in similar quantities across both models. The SF-1 additionally uses around 10–15 kg of adhesives and resins specific to composite bonding.

The total energy required for producing a prototype SF-1 is not precisely measurable at this stage, as multiple subsystems are externally sourced and production is not yet standardized. However, the labor-intensive nature of composite construction and the integration of electric components result in a significantly higher energy demand than for the metal-based Archer TX. This production-phase energy footprint is expected to decrease with industrial optimization and higher manufacturing volume.
ssf.sei_transport:
As detailed in the document Case Study Environmental Impact – Smartflyer SF-1, the materials and components used in the aircraft are primarily sourced from European suppliers and delivered using standard commercial freight logistics. The largest and heaviest structural components—namely the fuselage and wing modules, made of carbon fiber composites—are manufactured by Aerolite in Switzerland and transported by road freight to Smartflyer’s assembly site in Selzach. This minimizes transport emissions for core airframe parts. The electric motor is supplied by Emrax in Slovenia, and the inverter is produced by DTI in Hungary. The battery system, which constitutes a significant portion of the embedded energy in the aircraft, is developed by Emectric in Germany. The hybrid combustion engine is sourced from Rotax in Austria, while the generator is provided by YASA in the United Kingdom.

Other structural elements are also of European origin. For example, the landing gear is developed and fabricated in-house by Smartflyer in Switzerland using primarily aluminum. Acrylic windows and canopy parts are produced by Mecaplex, located nearby in Grenchen, Switzerland. Tires and wheels are supplied by Beringer Aero in France. These components account for most of the listed materials such as aluminum, copper, steel, rubber, and glass/acrylics.

Transport of small and medium-sized parts is typically conducted via regular shipping or parcel services, whereas larger elements use specialized freight. While exact transport energy data is not available, the overall logistics strategy emphasizes regional procurement and short supply chains where feasible. Raw material origin—such as for carbon fibers, lithium, or aluminum—cannot be traced precisely at this stage due to the complexity of upstream supply chains. Nonetheless, the current supply and transport setup reflects the prototype configuration and may be subject to change in future industrial production phases.
ssf.sei_use_phase:
As outlined in the document Case Study Environmental Impact – Smartflyer SF-1, the use phase is a resource-intensive part of an aircraft’s life cycle, especially in the context of flight training. The study compares the resource consumption of the Smartflyer SF-1 (in both battery-only and hybrid mode) with the Piper Archer TX over a representative annual operation time of 1,000 flight hours. The main resource required to operate an aircraft is fuel. Water consumption during use is negligible for both aircraft and is therefore not included in the quantitative analysis.

The Piper Archer TX, powered by a Lycoming IO-360-B4A combustion engine, consumes approximately 38 liters of AVGAS 100LL per hour. With an energy content of 31 MJ/liter, this results in an energy use of 327.2 kWh per hour or 327,222 kWh per year. It emits about 2.2 kg CO₂ per liter of fuel, totaling 83,600 kg CO₂ annually. Additionally, this fuel contains tetraethyl lead, contributing to localized pollution and health risks.

The Smartflyer SF-1 can operate in either fully electric or hybrid-electric mode. In battery-only operation, it consumes about 48 kWh of electricity per hour, totaling 48,000 kWh annually, with zero direct CO₂ emissions or fuel use. In hybrid mode, the aircraft combines a combustion-based range extender (Rotax 914) with electric propulsion. It consumes approximately 20 liters of fuel and 8 kWh of electricity per hour, resulting in 180.2 kWh/h energy use. This equates to 180,222 kWh annually, 20,000 liters of fuel, and 44,000 kg CO₂ emissions.

Even in hybrid mode, the SF-1 achieves an energy reduction of approximately 45% and a CO₂ emissions reduction of nearly 50% compared to the Archer TX. In battery-only operation, reductions exceed 85%. Moreover, the SF-1 eliminates lead emissions, with oil use estimated at 60 liters per year for both aircraft, based on typical usage data.
ssf.sei_disposal_phase:
As described in Section 5 of the Case Study Environmental Impact, the disposal of the aircraft’s materials is expected to follow a mixed strategy of reuse, recycling, and, where necessary, controlled disposal. A key advantage of the SF-1 is its modular architecture, particularly the detachable, nose-mounted energy module, which allows the airframe to be upgraded with future propulsion systems—such as new battery configurations or fuel cell units—without redesigning the entire structure. This design feature significantly extends the airframe’s operational lifetime, thereby reducing material turnover and minimizing end-of-life waste generation.

At the component level, most metallic parts—including aluminum, steel, and copper—are recoverable through established recycling processes. Aluminum from the landing gear and steel fasteners can be reprocessed efficiently, while copper from high-voltage wiring and electronic components is also suitable for material recovery. Lithium-ion batteries, which make up a large share of the hybrid energy system, will be subject to specialized recycling under hazardous materials regulations or will be reused in another role.

Composite materials, which form the majority of the SF-1’s airframe, are more difficult to handle at end of life. Current recycling methods for carbon composites are limited, but ongoing advancements in fiber recovery and pyrolysis offer potential for future reuse or downcycling. Additionally, some components may be repurposed in other aircraft platforms, subject to certification and compliance with aviation regulations.

Since the SFX1 remains in the prototype phase, final end-of-life strategies cannot yet be confirmed. The feasibility of recycling or reuse will depend on factors such as the regulatory framework, industrial partner capabilities, and technological developments in the composite recycling sector. As serial production is established, Smartflyer plans to adapt its disposal strategy accordingly.
ssf.ei_energy_consumption_1: The SF-1 reduces direct greenhouse gas emissions by up to 50% through its hybrid-electric propulsion and modular system. The aircraft’s exchangeable power unit module allows switching between battery and range extender units, enabling more efficient energy use and lower fuel-related emissions.
ssf.ei_air_pollution_1: The Smartflyer SF-1 reduces noise by up to 60% thanks to its electric motor and tail-mounted propeller, which minimizes mechanical and aerodynamic noise. This significantly lowers noise exposure, reducing stress and health strain for pilots and residents
ssf.ei_air_pollution_2: The Smartflyer SF-1 reduces direct CO₂ emissions by up to 50% compared to conventional training aircraft and eliminates lead emissions by not using AVGAS. This significantly lowers health risks for crews and residents near airfields exposed to air polluti
ssf.economic:
This case study examines the economic incentives for flight schools to adopt the Smartflyer SF-1 compared to the conventional Piper Archer TX, based on data presented in the Smartflyer Market Analysis. The analysis includes both direct purchase and leasing scenarios, assuming a typical annual utilization of 1,000 flight hours and a depreciation period of 12 years.

In a direct purchase model, the Smartflyer SF-1 has a higher acquisition cost at USD 750,000, compared to USD 550,000 for the Piper Archer TX. However, this difference is mitigated over time by significantly lower operating costs. The annual depreciation for the SF-1 is USD 62,500, while the Archer TX depreciates at USD 44,000 per year. Fixed annual costs are also slightly higher for the SF-1, estimated at around USD 20,000, compared to USD 17,000 for the Archer. In terms of maintenance, the SF-1 benefits from a simplified drivetrain and fewer moving parts, resulting in annual maintenance costs of approximately USD 7,000 to 9,000, whereas the Archer TX incurs higher costs in the range of USD 9,000 to 11,000 due to its combustion engine and more intensive servicing needs.

The most significant difference lies in hourly operating costs. For the Smartflyer SF-1, operating costs are estimated between USD 30 and 50 per flight hour, depending on the mode of operation and energy prices. In contrast, the Piper Archer TX incurs much higher operating costs, ranging between USD 80 and 100 per hour, primarily due to its use of AVGAS and higher maintenance demand. When all cost elements—depreciation, fixed costs, maintenance, and hourly operations—are combined, the total hourly cost of operating the SF-1 ranges from USD 120 to 150, while the Archer TX falls between USD 150 and 175 per hour.

When viewed over a full year, this means that the SF-1 has a total annual cost of approximately USD 120,000 to 150,000, compared to USD 150,000 to 175,000 for the Archer TX. Depending on operating conditions and local energy costs, this results in annual savings for the SF-1 of between USD 25,000 and 55,000. Over a 12-year lifecycle, total savings range from USD 300,000 to 660,000, making a strong case for long-term economic viability. The break-even point for the SF-1’s higher purchase price is typically reached between four and eight years into operation.

In a leasing model, Smartflyer envisions working with providers such as Green Aerolease to offer a monthly lease option for the SF-1, estimated at USD 9,000 per month, or USD 108,000 annually. When paired with the same operating cost assumptions of USD 30 to 50 per hour, the total annual cost of the leased SF-1 ranges from USD 138,000 to 158,000. This remains competitive with, and in some cases lower than, the annual ownership cost of the Archer TX, which remains between USD 150,000 and 175,000. Importantly, the leasing model eliminates the need for upfront capital investment, lowers financial risk, and allows schools to adopt the aircraft more easily.

Overall, the economic advantages of the Smartflyer SF-1 are clear. Despite a higher acquisition cost, its lower maintenance and operating costs translate into a substantially better cost structure over time. The electric and hybrid propulsion system not only reduces fuel dependency but also positions operators to benefit from future regulatory incentives and cost pressures related to emissions and noise. Whether leased or purchased, the SF-1 offers flight schools a financially compelling and operationally sustainable path forward.
ssf.economic_intensity_detail:
The initial capital intensity of the Smartflyer SF-1 depends on the chosen acquisition model but is generally moderate to high in the case of direct purchase and low when leased. In the direct purchase scenario, the aircraft requires an upfront investment of USD 750,000, which represents approximately 42% to 50% of the total cost of ownership over a 12-year lifecycle. Assuming 1,000 flight hours per year and total ownership costs of USD 120,000 to 150,000 annually, the lifetime cost sums to USD 1.44 to 1.8 million. The initial investment therefore constitutes a significant portion of the total expenditure, particularly when compared to the relatively low annual operating costs (USD 30–50/hour) and fixed costs (USD 20,000/year).

In contrast, in the leasing scenario, the capital intensity is significantly lower. With an estimated monthly lease rate of USD 9,000, or USD 108,000 annually, the adopter avoids any large upfront payment. All costs are distributed across the usage period, with the lease and operational expenses occurring proportionally over time. In this model, the capital intensity is below 10%, comparable to other low-CAPEX service-based models. This lowers the financial barrier to adoption, especially for smaller flight schools that operate on tight budgets and prioritize cash flow over asset ownership.

Overall, the Smartflyer SF-1 offers adopters flexibility. For those choosing to buy, the model behaves similarly to traditional aviation assets, with medium to high capital intensity but long-term cost efficiency. For operators choosing leasing, the solution behaves more like a service model, making it financially accessible and low-risk from a capital deployment perspective.
ssf.ef_total_cost_1: Over 12 years and 1,000 flight hours annually, the Smartflyer SF-1 can reduce total ownership costs by up to USD 660,000 compared to a mainstream solution, due to lower operating and maintenance costs, despite a higher initial purchase price.
ssf.ef_total_cost_2: Thanks to operating cost savings of up to USD 55,000 per year, the Smartflyer SF-1 reaches its financial break-even point compared to a mainstream solution within 4 to 8 years, depending on energy prices and utilization levels.

partners.name: Airbus Foundation
partners.short_description: Airbus Foundation and Solar Impulse Foundation join forces to leverage aerospace technology for nature-based climate resilience
partners.header_title: Unlocking access to Airbus products, services and expertise to address today’s pressing societal challenges
partners.header_intro: At Airbus, we recognise that global developments like climate change, poverty and increasing inequality are serious issues that are relevant to us all. In response, we focus on supporting communities with solutions they can own, that are scalable and deliver a long-term benefit. We target two broad priority areas: enabling communities most exposed to humanitarian crises and climate change to adapt and build resilience; and widening youth access to essential future knowledge and skills.
partners.header_text: The Airbus Foundation is our vehicle to unlock access to Airbus products and services, collaborating with NGO partners to respond to humanitarian crises, natural disasters and environmental challenges, with a focus also on strengthening resilience. In addition, the Airbus Foundation supports educators worldwide through developing quality educational resources, inspired by the aerospace industry and addressing complex societal challenges such as artificial intelligence.
partners.vision_title: Airbus Foundation and Solar Impulse Foundation join forces to leverage aerospace technology for nature-based climate resilience
partners.vision_intro: Driven by a shared commitment to sustainability and innovation, Airbus Foundation and Solar Impulse Foundation collaborate to leverage the capabilities and expertise of both foundations.
partners.vision_text: The partnership aims to identify and accelerate the adoption of scalable nature-based projects  to enhance climate resilience. At the heart is a series of calls for projects to support organisations developing solutions to societal challenges, from driving climate change mitigation and adaptation, to addressing food security and human health concerns.
partners.vision_quote_1: Aerospace technologies can unlock information about our planet that we cannot access from the ground. By combining these capabilities from Airbus with Solar Impulse Foundation’s expertise in supporting climate projects, we can create new pathways for innovation to strengthen climate resilience.
partners.vision_quote_1_author: Julie Kitcher, Airbus Chief Sustainability Officer and Chair of the Airbus Foundation
partners.vision_quote_2: By combining aerospace technology with nature-based solutions, we can turn innovation into impact. Our partnership with the Airbus Foundation demonstrates how advanced capabilities like satellite imagery can help restore ecosystems, support economic development, and build climate resilience where it’s needed most.
partners.vision_quote_2_author: Bertrand Piccard, Initiator and Chairman of the Solar Impulse Foundation
partners.commitment_title: Pioneering sustainable aerospace for a safe and united world
partners.commitment_intro: Aerospace unites people, drives economic prosperity, and supports global stability.
